characters: START A FIRE WITHOUT A SPARK. THIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We open on a mirror in a beautiful, ornate bathroom. Suddenly a man comes up from below frame with water dripp off his face. A bathroom attendant leans in and turns the faucet off for him as he hands him a towel. The man says “Thank you”. This is STEVE BUTLER. A man in his late 30's handsome, and reminiscent of a guy you went to college wi As he dries his face he looks at himself. After a long be he takes a deep breath. And walks out into: An enormous beautiful main room of a restaurant. We follo Steve as he walks through the restaurant that drips with leaf and marble. As we take in this almost surreal room.. the title card comes up across the screen.

dialogues.speaker: PROMISED LAND
dialogues.text: We follow the man as he finally arrives at his table. The aman sits checking his blackberry. This is David Churchil aman in his early 50’s and the CFO of Global Crosspower Solutions; one of the largest energy corporations in the country. An impeccably dressed waitress comes to the tabl behind Steve.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: Can I get either of you gentlemen anything else?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You want another drink?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I'm fine thanks.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (To waitress) We'll have another bottle of the Chateau Margaux. Waitress leaves.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You'll be fine! David checks his watch.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Listen, I’m sorry Michael isn’t here yet. His plane was delayed getting into Teterboro.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Oh, that’s no problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He likes to meet every executive candidate, it’s kind of a tradition... or a neuroses.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Well, that’s nice of him.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: It is actually. Until he does his one joke. “I thought you said he wasn’t handsome.” Steve laughs.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: An oldie but a goodie. The waitress comes back with the bottle of wine and shows David the label. He nods.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: What time you heading out tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Well, Sue’s already there. I was actually going to catch the last bus tonight. Be there to get started first thing tomorrow morning.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Sue Thomason, right? Jesus! That was the first thing they said about you two. You don’t stop.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Well, I don’t know about that.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I do. It’s why we're talking right now.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (Tastes wine. To waitress) Great. (to Steve as she pours) When we called the office out West you were the only name they gave us.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Well, that’s really nice. Waitress exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, Steve, this is a 9 billion dollar company. If someone is recommending you? It’s not nice... it’s numbers.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I appreciate that.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You are the only person from the field we're interviewing. This lands on Steve.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Let me ask you something. You guys have closed more towns than the team behind you by triple digits. And your total price point on what we pay out on your leases is almost half of everyone else’s. How do you do that?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I mean, I grew up in Eldridge, Iowa.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: «+. Meaning?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: It might as well have been Rifle, Colorado; Dish, Texas or Lafayette, Louisiana. Any of the places we’ve sold. They know me. And I know them.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Well, unfortunately it seems the rest of our road teams don’t see it as quite so easy.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: .-. I grew up in a large farming community. (He rolls his eyes) Football Fridays, tractor pulls, cow tipping, all of it. David smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was also one of two in my graduating class who went to college-- well, who decided to pursue something other than agriculture. Biggest fight my grandfather and I ever had.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: There’s just a pride, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: It’s delusional self mythologizing. And it’s bullshit. We had a Caterpillar plant down in Davenport a few miles away. David nods.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: My junior year in high school they closed it down. I remember thinking nothing of it. By the time prom came around I got to see, first hand, just how little legs we had to stand on. The whole farming town fantasy was shattered. And what became real clear was that without that plant, without that industry? We had nothing. And the town was just... David is nodding.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I’m not selling them Natural Gas. I’m selling them their only way to get back.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: .-. Well, that brings me to my second question which is why the hell would we take you off the road??? Steve laughs. David looks behind Steve and notices something. He raises his glass.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (To Steve) Best of luck, Steve. They cheers. Suddenly from behind Steve:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this the guy? A man in his 50's walks up to the table. This is Michael Downey, the obvious CEO of Global.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I thought you said he wasn’t handsome! Steve smiles. Michael sits down in the booth.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Sorry I’m late. Had to stop at home on my way. My 11 year daughter dissected a frog in science class today. She will not stop crying. All the men chuckle.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: 11 years old, can you believe it? Is that too young? I didn’t dissect a frog until senior year in high school. I mean is that even necessary? The men acknowledge that’s true.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: (To David) Ah, what are ya’ gonna do? After moment... David turns to Steve. Now both men look a Steve. Was this a legitimate question? In a fraction of a second:

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: It’s absolutely necessary. It’s the pursuit of knowledge. Sure, the frog is sacrificed. But, in the name of progress. If your daughter doesn’t dissect a frog, how will she ever learn to perform a triple bypass? Beat.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Her tears notwithstanding, this has to happen whether she understands it or not. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like getting a vaccine, your kid might cry a second from the jab, but she ain’t gonna die of polio. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Tell her the good news is it gets easier. After a beat... Michael smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the first minutes of a cool Spring day we see a idylli landscape of a blood orange colored sky hanging above the tree covered mountains of McKinley, a small town at the f of a mountain. In the distant foreground of this pictures still life we see two windows illuminated in a charming, slightly run down, farm house. To the right and left of t house we see seemingly unending land, low lit to an almos surreal color and covered in perfectly placed hay bales. unusual sound can be heard... a grunting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A charming older woman in her 70's exits the squeaky scre door carrying a cup of coffee. She wears an apron and wal with confidence. By the barn we see a pick up truck. Suddenly a man in his late 70’s exits the barn. He wears flannel shirt with sleeves rolled up and very lived in je From the back of the truck he grabs an enormous bag of fe with the ease of a sack of potatoes. He immediately disappears once again into the barn. After a moment, the woman arrives outside the barn and waits. As the man exit

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Well... any other horses and I'd say that should last the rest of the month.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: So we’ll need more by Friday.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: (Smiling) Sounds about right. The woman hands him the cup of coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. The woman smiles and pats the man on the back. As he head to his truck.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: I’1l bring this one back.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Oh yeah? Bring the other five while you're at it. She holds up a powder blue mug.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: This is the only one I’ve got left!

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Yes ma’am. He gets into his truck and pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From up above we see the bus as it rolls through beautifu farm land.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve sits on a bus looking out the window at the pastora landscape as it passes by.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT TRUCK
dialogues.text: The man is drinking his coffee as the truck drives throug this incredibly beautiful farmland. He waves out the wind to a couple of men standing in a pasture with a large num of cattle. As the truck pulls up to an intersection and turns right see a very small church on the corner... the slight beginnings of a town center. Arriving to a stop light the truck pauses. Then with the audible flick of a green light the truck turns onto the t of Main St., the epicenter of this area. In the low light the morning the small stretch is almost picturesque, but the truck rumbles on we see the reality of the more moder small town America.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Interspersed with the more common necessities like a coff shop and barber shop are a number of boarded up windows a empty store fronts. The truck finally rumbles out of frame as we hold on the exterior of a motel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve exits from the motel and begins to walk across the parking lot. He is checking his blackberry. He looks up a we cut to: A woman in her 50’s standing in front of a very used Ford Bronco. This is SUE THOMASON. She’s attractive, put-toget and Steve's leasing partner for the past 6 years... But m often then not she feels like his big sister. She wears j and a light sweater over a plaid shirt.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Good morning.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Do I have to call you ‘Boss’ now?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Will you stop. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: They’11 let me know. Sue smiles.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (referencing the car) This is the best you could do?

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: No. But, I wasn’t looking for the best, was I?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: You know what I mean. He heads past her toward the driver’s side door.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Stick! Steve immediately stops, familiar with this moment, and i one motion is heading back around to the passenger side.. doesn’t drive stick shift.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: You do it on purpose.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: You're right, I do... boss.  They get in. In a wide shot we hear Sue try to start the car. It doesn’t turn over.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Worth it? The car starts.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Suck it! INT/EXT BRONCO - ROB’S GUNS, GROCERY, GUITARS AND GAS - D Sue and Steve are driving. Steve looks at a map, drinking bottle of water.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Girl at the hotel said it’s right around here. Has everything. Steve looks up as Sue pulls into a small parking lot. The look up at the sign that says ‘Rob’s Guns, Grocery, Guita and Gas.’ Sue reads aloud:

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: “Rob's Guns, Grocery, Guitars and Gas.”

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: (marveling at the sign) God, I wish I thought of that. INT. ROB’S GUNS, GROCERY, GUITARS AND GAS - DAY 7 Steve and Sue walk through to the back of a small local s that seems like it might actually have everything.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Where'd they put you up? Four Seasons?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: The Pierre.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Jesus! They keep walking. Steve smiles.  10

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: And, I was right, this is the entry point for the whole state.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: I love it! Feels like dominoes.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: It is. They arrive at a few racks of clothes and begin carefully picking out clothes. Sue grabs a few flannel shirts.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: What season is this? Do they even still wear flannel now?

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Oh please, up here, they always wear flannel.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: «-.- Or camo.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: I’m not wearing camo.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: How was Houston? How’s Danny?

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: He’s 15. He’s gone... but he started baseball. Made varsity.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: As a freshman? Sue, that’s huge!

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: I guess. His first game is this weekend and my missing it will go to the top of the list of things he'll cover with his shrink at 45.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Hey, someone’s gotta pay for his xbox. Steve picks up a pair of work gloves.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: You need a new pair?  11

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: I never use them.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: That’s a yes. Ok, you ready?

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Boots! Steve looks down at his boots. They are Caterpillar work boots.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I’m not going over this again, Sue. These are the best boots money can buy and they’re made in America. Sue looks at him confused.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Yeah, but yours are old. Sue walks away to the check out counter, which is actuall gun case. Steve follows. Behind the counter is one rack o larger guns and sure enough... a rack of guitars.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: (Staring at the guitars) Wow, you really have them. The man behind the counter looks up from a book. This is ROB. He is about 40, and in his black jeans, collared shi and vest he doesn’t look like what you’d imagine a local look like.

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: So I take it you’re not here to buy a guitar. Sue smiles and looks for a credit card in her wallet.

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: You’re the natural gas people. Sue is taken aback.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry?

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: Apologizing right off the bat, I like it! It’s endearing and vulnerable and yet... honest and direct.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sue doesn’t know what to say. She almost looks back at St but thinks better of it.  12

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: (Pointing at her wallet) The ID card is kind of a dead give away. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: ‘Bout time you all showed up.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: Well, hell yes. What other choice we got? We can’t sell the scenery!

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Wow... wanna come work for us?

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: What... and leave all this? He sarcastically gestures to his weird store. Sue smiles.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT BRONCO
dialogues.text: Sue is driving. They are both now wearing brand new cloth Steve is drinking from a bottle of water.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: I can’t believe this so close to the city. Looks like Kentucky.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Two hours outside any city is Kentucky. You should know that. Sue notices a group of horses by the road.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Hey... Does something seem weird about those horses? They both look out to the side of the road. There are 6 o horses, with long, almost decorative, manes.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: No. Not really. (squinting) Wait. Are they small?  10 13

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: They seem very small. Could they be that small? My eyesight’s going.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Maybe they're ponies?

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: (emphatically) They’re not ponies!!... I mean I guess they could be ponies...

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Remember new region, so we can go as high as 5000 and 18%. But it doesn’t mean we have to. Beat. The car is slowing down.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Don’t ponies have big heads? Like, proportionally? Sue pulls over to the side of the road. She hands Steve a clipboard with a complicated looking list of names, addre and other figures. He is checking his blackberry again. H hops out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the Bronco is parked at the base of a long dirt driveway leading up to a rather dilapidated farmhouse. Th Bronco and the house seem like mere specks in the middle the seemingly endless landscape around them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve walks up to the house where a young girl is pushing small toy lawn mower out front.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Hello there! Are you the owner of this place?

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: No, sir.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: No? Well then how come you’re doing all the work?  14

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: (Smiling) I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Well, who do I talk to about that? The girl laughs and begins to lead him into the house.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: My Dad.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Well, alright then, let’s go inside and straighten all this out! Steve smiles and gently pats the girl’s head as the two w toward the stairs. At the top, a man opens the screen doo This is DREW SCOTT.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Didn't they already finish the census?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: No, I’m not from the census. I’m from a Natural Gas company. You have a second? Steve and the girl get to the top of the steps.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Oh, hell! Why didn’t you say so! Come on in!

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: You just go shopping? Steve looks up at him. Drew gestures to his neck.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: You got a tag stickin’ out of your collar. He reaches over and yanks the tag from Steve’s collar.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: There ya go.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: So much for looking local.  11 15 As Steve crosses the threshold Drew looks down.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Nice boots. Steve’s smile is bigger than it should be.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sue sits in a sparse living room with a woman in her late 20's. She is naturally pretty and very sweet. This is CLAIRE ALLEN. Suddenly a 10 year old comes by and sets do 2 glasses of red Hi-C for the woman and for Sue. He is wearing a t-shirt with YANKEES written in marker on the f and the number ‘15’ written on the back along with his la name, ALLEN.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Thanks Carson.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Thanks. Wild color, right? (puts the glass down without touching it. This does not go unnoticed by Claire) Sue points at Carson's watch.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Is that Thor?

dialogues.speaker: CARSON
dialogues.text: No, it’s IRONMAN. He shows her.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Oooh, my son would love that! She pretends to take it. Carson laughs.

dialogues.speaker: CARSON
dialogues.text: Nooo! He walks away.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: You have kids Ms. Thomason?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pulls out phone) Yes I do. Danny. 15 and ornery.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: He looks sweet.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Yours is sweeter. The two women laugh. Carson re-enters.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Mom, can I play xbox?

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Just for a bit. And only because you're going outside for baseball in an hour.

dialogues.speaker: CARSON
dialogues.text: Sweet!

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: (For Sue’s benefit) Sorry about that. I know I shouldn't let him..

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Are you kidding! Of course! From the minute we meet them and see their little squishy faces we'd do anything for 'em!... Anything. Carson nods and leaves. Claire turns back to Sue.

dialogues.speaker: 15A
dialogues.text: We can see Carson in the background playing Xbox for the rest of scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 16 12 Steve now sits at the kitchen table with DREW. His daught is coloring at the table as well.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Oh man, have we been waiting on you!

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Oh yeah?

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: It’s unbelievable! I was just reading in the paper THIS MORNING about all that gas drillin’ goin’ on in Pennsylvania. He looks at the paper.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: This your outfit? ‘Stanton Gas’? Steve glances over casually.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: No, there are a bunch of companies. We're with ‘Global Crosspower Solutions’.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Well, you guys are probably the best!

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: You wanna come work for us? The two men laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sue sits with Claire. 13  17

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Here’s the thing, Claire. And it’s important that you know this... The initial phase of development for drilling is ALSO the initial phase of the town’s tax revenue. Which means money will be injected into the town and its infrastructure immediately!

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: That sounds impressive.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: I know, a lot of fancy words. But here’s what it means to me. The number one reason I chose to live where I do is for the school that my boy goes to. I just want what most parents want for their kids. Everything. And that everything starts with his education.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: You sound like a good mother.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Far from good. Honest maybe. Do you think your town's school system is underfunded?

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: In a school system like yours, the chances of Carson going to college are too low. And in today's market, without a college degree, the only jobs available are manual labor... and those jobs are going... if not gone. TECHNOLOGY is our sons' future.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Yes!! We tried to get a computer system for the kids last year but it never happened.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Well, there's no reason why your town shouldn't have a state of the art high school and your son guaranteed an education that allows him to compete on the highest level. He'll have a chance... Beat. This registers with Claire.  18

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve and Drew at the kitchen table.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Our leases start at $2000.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Wait... that’s it?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Well, that’s not necessarily life changing money, is it?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Per acre. And you have 20. Now, there are a lot of people around here that would say $40,000, well, that’s pretty good money... Especially for doing nothing. Drew wipes sweat off his face. Looks at Steve.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: But, the real reason I’m here in this early stage is because our research shows that your particular plot of land has a potentially “high yield”. That means that not only the size of the deposit, but the quality of the shale is in the top tier. Drew, as if watching a thriller movie.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Mm Hm...

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Now we at Global don’t want to be tenants... We want to be partners. That’s why we offer an 12 anda half percent share in any and all profits we see from your wells.  15 19

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: And with this... this top tier level of shit, what kind of figures are we looking at?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Well, it’s hard to tell until we get down there, but--

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Ballpark, man! Like other people who have had a similar situation? Beat...

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Millions...

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Wait.. What do you mean? Like, you guys... uh...

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: You...... Could be. A millionaire. Drew’s look is ... elated? Scared? Dead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve walks into the nearly empty diner that looks like a time capsule. He sees a man wave his hand and joins him i vinyl booth in the back. The man is GERRY RICHARDS, he’s about 60 years old and one of McKinley’s three town supervisors. Steve introduces himself and sits down.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Supervisor Richards? Steve Butler.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARDS
dialogues.text: Call me Gerry for God's sake. A waitress comes over to the table and drops 2 menus.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: Anything to drink?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARDS
dialogues.text: Steve?  20

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I‘1ll have a cup of coffee.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: And, you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARDS
dialogues.text: I’m fine thanks. She exits.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARDS
dialogues.text: Well, listen, I appreciate you sitting down with me here, I know you're busy so I just thought it might be nice to meet before the town hall tomorrow so we can get to know each other a little bit.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Of course! Listen, as the most senior member of the supervisors board thank YOU for sitting down with ME. Appreciate it. Richards laughs.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARDS
dialogues.text: It’s exciting all this natural gas stuff.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: It is! Very exciting!

dialogues.speaker: RICHARDS
dialogues.text: (Leans in and whispers with a smile) A whole lot of money down there! Steve laughs.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: That’s also true, yes!

dialogues.speaker: RICHARDS
dialogues.text: How much do you think? (He gestures) How much money we got down there?  Beat. 21

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Well, our research department hasn't finished their analysis yet but I’d say somewhere between 15 or 20 million dollars!

dialogues.speaker: RICHARDS
dialogues.text: Is that right?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Could be! Lynn returns with a cup of coffee and a creamers.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARDS
dialogues.text: So, I’ve been doing a little research about all this, gone online a little bit. And well, I’ve read all these rumblings of Natural Gas possibly contaminating water sources? Killing crops and what not?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I understand your concern. I’ve read all those stories myself. And let me assure you--

dialogues.speaker: RICHARDS
dialogues.text: People lighting their water on fire? People getting sick? That sounds nasty.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: These are just scare tactics--

dialogues.speaker: RICHARDS
dialogues.text: I have a responsibility to protect these people. To ensure their safety. And, well, to be honest I’m just not sure I’m too comfortable telling my constituents to allow you folks into our town. No matter how much money you have.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Mr. Richards--

dialogues.speaker: RICHARDS
dialogues.text: There’s a lot of people counting on me, Steve and not just in this town. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: RICHARDS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: People look to me in the next town and the next town. You see, I have the opportunity to set a precedent here.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Look, there are answers to everything you just brought up--

dialogues.speaker: RICHARDS
dialogues.text: Now, I know you all have quite an operation in the works, here. Plans to set up all throughout the state. I’d hate to be the guy to jeopardize all that for you. Steve looks up. Richards is looking directly at him. He h a smile on his face... a different smile.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARDS
dialogues.text: To lead this one little “podunk” town to reject your company. To reject natural Gas. I mean I can’t even imagine what that would mean for you guys. (Richards changes) And if that story got around? In the papers? On the news? Can you imagine? What that would do to your balance sheet? There’s a long beat. Both men stare each other down.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARDS
dialogues.text: What’s that?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: We can offer you 30,000 dollars. The waitress comes back to the table.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: Can I get you anything else?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARDS
dialogues.text: (Without breaking his stare at Steve) You know what, Lynn, I think we're done here. Just the check please. She exits. Richards grabs his jacket. Then he pulls out a small note pad.  23

dialogues.speaker: RICHARDS
dialogues.text: (Reading) The Marcellus shale. Estimated at 2 TRILLION dollars. With BILLIONS in potential tax revenue to individual states. Back to Steve.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARDS
dialogues.text: Google. First one that came up... First sentence... Now do you wanna re-think that joke number you mentioned earlier?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Mr. Richards, I’m just being straight with you here. It’s simple math. Best case scenario there’s 30 million dollars under your town. .1% of that is 30,000 dollars. They want me to offer as low as 10 in these situations. But, you seem like a smart guy so I’m telling you we have 30. Richards reaches for his jacket. Steve sips coffee.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: «+. But, I’m also telling you this is a one time offer. Richard stops and looks at Steve.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Don’t do this. I’ve been here before and it doesn’t end well. You don’t wanna be last. You're right, we have teams in place in towns all over this state... and the next state. And the next state. We’re all the way up to Maine now. And every one of those towns are signing fast. Richards smiles, saying nothing.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Look, I don’t fault you for trying. But, I’m telling you-- hell, I’m begging you. Don’t do this. Because the truth is we will walk away. We always do... (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: STEVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And then after every single town within 3 states has signed up and the blows of this economy are almost unbearable... we’1ll come back. And we'll offer you nothing. We'll offer this town nothing. Every lease we’ve signed, every piece of the pie we've offered. It all goes away... and we buy this place for nothing. Richards’ face has changed.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Let some other guy be last. The waitress comes back to the table with the check. He hands her a 20 dollar bill.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Thank you. Steve stands up.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: So, I'll see you tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARDS
dialogues.text: I’1ll see you tomorrow. Steve exits leaving Richards there to contemplate what could've just happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sue and Steve walk down the hallway. Steve is, once again checking his blackberry. Sue stops at a door and opens it

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Nice job today.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Kind of anti-climactic. I thought it'd harder. This one’s easy!

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: They always are.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Well, good let’s wrap this up and get the hell out of here early. Maybe I can fly home for the weekend game before we head upstate.  17 25 Steve is still looking at his blackberry. Suddenly... he freezes. Long beat. Sue notices.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: What? He turns back to her.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (quietly) I got it. Sue smiles. After possibly a moment too long she walks ov and gives now see... She gives and turns She turns him a hug. With her face over his shoulder, we can her conflict.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: ... That’s great. him a motherly kiss on the cheek. Then sniffles back to her door so Steve doesn’t see her tears.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: I’m proud of you.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Sue! back.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Buy the plane ticket tonight. I/’11 even pay for it.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Cocky bastard. She goes into her room. Steve turns and walks down the hallway. As the news final sinks in, he smiles huge. Music begins to play as we:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welcome to ‘Buddy's’, the center of social life in McKinl It’s warm and welcoming, a cross between hunting lodge an dive bar. There’s a long bar and an adjacent dining area, U- shaped around a small stage. About a dozen animals, mostl deer and moose, are mounted on the wall. The place is ful beer signs and photos of locals with big catches and hunt with one foot on dead 10-point bucks.  26 Steve is at the bar, drinking a scotch. Next to him is hi plastic bottle of water. The bartender, an enormous man i his 60's who is obviously the leader of a motorcycle gang pours him another scotch from a very dusty bottle.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: You want me to leave the bottle?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Uh... yeah, sure. Thanks. He takes a sip.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Three more, Jesse.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Well, goddamn. Steve turns to see a young woman at the bar.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Don’t judge me Jesse, it’s my birthday.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: I didn’t say nothin’. This is ALICE. There’s a part of her that’s likely still Girl Next Door, but the part we meet is a bit rough aroun the edges. She’s pretty without trying and she knows it. is her birthday, a fact that is quite apparent from how t she is. Alice looks over and sees Steve looking at her. He immediately turns away.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Lemme guess. 40. Marketing. Married. 2 kids. Steve doesn’t look up.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: 38. Stripper/Waitress but was “born” to be a singer.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Hey, asshole I’m a teacher! Steve finally turns to her for the first time.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I was talking about me.  27 Alice wants to laugh but doesn’t.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: You're a waitress?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Times are tough. Beat. Without taking his eyes off of her.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Do you want a dance? 100 bucks per song. Alice finally laughs.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: That’s insane. I wouldn’t pay 30! Steve still not giving in.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: You haven’t seen my moves.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Ok, now you're creeping me out. Steve finally laughs. Reaches to shake her hand.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Steve.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Alice. Jesse brings back 3 Budweiser bottles and 3 Jack Daniels shots.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: You’re goin’ big for a school night.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: It's my birthday.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Really. Well, tomorrow.  28

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Do they give you the day off for your birthday? Or do you just tell the kids you’ve got a stomach bug.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: First off, I resent the implication that I can’t hold my liquor... And secondly... the first two periods we watch videos.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: So what?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: What brings you to our booming metropolis?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Well, I’m from a small town myself so it feels a lot like home.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Oh yeah? Where’s that?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Eldridge, Iowa.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Ah, you're a buckeye!

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: That’s Ohio, actually.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Same thing.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Ok. Steve smiles. From off camera we hear a group of girls ye

dialogues.speaker: GROUP
dialogues.text: Alice, let’s go! Steve looks over to see three girls at a table against th wall. They are Alice’s friends, the one yelling is GWEN, full-figured and loud -- she thinks she’s Bette Midler.  29

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Well, it was nice meeting you.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: You even gonna buy a girl a birthday drink?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: That would communicate the wrong thing.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: (smiling) You’re an asshole.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Of course I'll buy your drinks.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Absolutely not, you lost your chance. Gwen yells again from the table. As Alice looks, Steve stares at her and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: GWEN
dialogues.text: What are we doin’? We drinkin’ or not? Alice looks back at Steve.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: How long you in town?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Uhh-- a bit. I’m gonna be around for a bit.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: You’re gonna be “Around for a bit?” ++. You're a terrible liar.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I’m not lying! Alice smiles, skeptical.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Well, you wanna give a girl a real birthday gift? Steve smiles. Seems a little forward, but hey!  30

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Sure. Alice doesn’t break eye contact with Steve. After a beat.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Jesse, we're playing ABSOLUT MADNESS. Steve, still smiling, is confused.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: What’s ABSOLUT MADNESS?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: It's pretty much what it sounds like. You and Jesse both drink 5 shots in 5 minutes and if you can get closer to the bulls eye on that dartboard we drink for free and you get your Polaroid on the wall. She points behind the bar to a line of Polaroids of men completely annihilated.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: That’s not at all what it sounds like. I’m in. Jesse begins setting up shot glasses. And slams down a bottle of Absolut vodka. Other people in the bar start gathering to watch. Steve notices.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: How bout this! We drink 8 shots in 8 minutes and EVERYONE here drinks for free! Jesse looks to Alice concerned. She laughs knowingly.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Sure! Every one cheers! Jesse shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Good luck! As the men grab their first shots and cheers each other w

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve is dead asleep on a couch that is too small for him is covered in what looks like a hand made blanket. He is jarred awake... by nothing. He takes in his surroundings. All of a sudden we see Alic sitting at a small table. She is completely dressed and r for the day. She drinks a cup of coffee as she reads the morning paper online.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Oh thank God, you’re still pretty handsome. He stares at her for a moment putting the pieces of his h back together.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: You're late.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Your phone hasn’t stop buzzing for the last half hour. Steve checks his phone. Sees the missed calls and more importantly, he sees the time. He is very late.

dialogues.speaker: SHIT
dialogues.text: He immediately jumps up... that wasn’t a good idea. He flinches for a split second. Then begins quickly getting dressed. (He is wearing the same shirt but just boxers.)

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Listen, I had a really great time.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Did you?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Well... I just mean--

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Nothing happened, Steve. Beat. Steve is confused.  32

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Well, actually you did kiss me just before you threw up the first time.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Oh my God! I’m really sorry. Thank you... for letting me stay.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: It’s fine. I was gonna let you sleep in your car, but you couldn't remember which one was yours.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I didn’t drive. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Well then it’s a good thing I didn’t let you sleep in your car. Steve is now basically dressed. A dreaded part of the morning.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: So... can I take your number?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: You’re gonna be “around for a bit”, right?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Uh---

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: It’s not that big a town. You'll see me again. Steve is still putting everything together.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: O-- Ok. Is the-- Is the door--?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: At the front of the house. When you get to it, you’ll find a knob. Turn the knob and --

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Oh god. Too early for that. Beat.  19 33

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Well... Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Your welcome. In a daze, Steve goes to leave. Then comes back again.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Hey, happy birthday! He leaves. Alice smiles.

dialogues.speaker: EXT MOTEL
dialogues.text: Sue, in the car, is in the foreground talking on the phon Out the driver side window we see a tiny blurry figure th we are not paying attention to. As Sue continues to talk the phone, the blurry figure gets closer and closer, then stops... is it bending over to catch his breath? Or retching?

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: What’s wrong?... Because you called me 3 times... What?... What do you mean you were burned?... Why were you using an iron?.... He asked YOU to do it? Fantastic!... I highly doubt it’s burned OFF, Danny. What did the nurse say? Throwing hand or catching hand? So can you play this weekend? What you mean pitch? When did the coach say that? Danny, that’s AMAZING! Finally the blur continues to come closer until he is rig up at the window exhausted... and nauseous. It’s Steve. Instinctually, Sue slowly turns her head and stares at hi Steve pops up. Through the glass we hear:

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: 5 minutes! He pauses, taking one more second to recover. Then runs o of frame.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: No, no, I’m just at work. Hey, guess what? I’1l be there! I booked it last night... Hello? Danny, can you hear me?... I’m losing you.  20 21 34 She hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People file into a large high school gymnasium.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At half court there are 3 people sitting in folding chair the town supervisors. In the bleachers facing them are ab 400 people finding seats. Supervisor Richards is standing front of the crowd. He briefly looks over by the door to side of the bleachers where tucked away, just out of view Steve and Sue look on. Steve holds a bottle of water. A man is whispering in Richards ear. Richards acknowledge and speaks:

dialogues.speaker: RICHARDS
dialogues.text: Ok, if everyone could find a seat we'll begin in a moment. Thank you. Steve is typing on his blackberry. Sue looks at Richards drinks a lemonade.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: He all set?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Yeah, he’s on board. What is that?

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Lemonade.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Is it good?

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: GREAT! Fresh squeezed. There’s a kid selling it out there. She’s cleaning up! You want one?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (Holding up bottle of water) No. People are still filing in by Sue and Steve. Most of them carry lemonades.  35

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: How many do we have.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Signed 14 today. So that’s 27. Think we’ll only need the one more day.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: I still can’t believe that’s why you were late this morning? We got back from dinner at 930!

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: She was very cool. You’d like her.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: You don’t want to make statements like that just yet. Name?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Alice.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Alice? ... Sue stops and looks over.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: ... Was she elderly? Steve shoots her a look as Richards begins to speak.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARDS
dialogues.text: Ok, I appreciate you all coming today. Unfortunately there seems to have been a scheduling error so we'll have to make this quick... Well, this is quite a turn out! We're not used to standing room only. I must be doing something right! Richards gives a politician’s smile. People murmur a response.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARDS
dialogues.text: Ok, let’s get right to it. Now, I know some of you have been hearing dribs and drabs about all this natural gas stuff. Maybe some of you even have family or friends who have had natural gas come to their town. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: RICHARDS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: In which case, I’m sure you’ve heard, then, what a life changing opportunity it is. Creating HUNDREDS of jobs, and therefore millions of dollars in revenue and large injections of funding into town infrastructure. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARDS
dialogues.text: Well, I am very happy to announce that we will be bringing natural gas to McKinley! There is a burst of applause. Sue and Steve notice. Suddenly a voice bursts out from the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: How do they get the gas?? Everyone looks for the voice, including Richards and Sue. Steve looks up for a brief second but finishes whatever e mail he’s working on. Richards spots the source of the voice. This is FRANK YAT He is about 70 years old, but his level of physical strength... and calm strength of spirit, is apparent immediately. We recognize him as the man who drove the tr in the credit sequence.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERVISOR RICHARDS
dialogues.text: Ah! How are ya, Frank? If you wouldn't mind just holding on for one minute, there’1ll be time for questions at the end. Now, the company we'll be working with is called Global Crosspower Solutions and--

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I apologize, I was just wondering how it all works, that’s all. We can see members of the crowd now turning back to Richa to hear his response. Steve, again, looks up. He is completely confident in his new employee.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERVISOR RICHARDS
dialogues.text: Well, its a rather complex process... Beat. People wait for a response.  37

dialogues.speaker: SUPERVISOR RICHARDS
dialogues.text: But I will, uh, explain it as simply as I can... There are, uh, rock deposits underground. Deep, under ground. MILES underground! And what they do is create these drills that go 2 or 3 miles down and break up the rock... shale, it’s called shale. And that breaking of the rock is what actually releases the gas--

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Its called Fracking.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERVISOR RICHARDS
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: The process. Its called Fracking.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERVISOR RICHARDS
dialogues.text: That's right. That’s right. Now, Frank if you’d just let me finish please I--

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I would encourage all of you to go home and Google this word and see what you find. Unfortunately, it’s not nearly as simple as what Supervisor Richards just laid out. Now, listen, it’s true there is some money to be made having this industry coming in, but can we at least not pretend that it is not without cost. Without taking her eyes off Frank, Sue hits Steve’s arm, has finally looked up from his blackberry.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Just...hold on.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERVISOR RICHARDS
dialogues.text: Frank, now, I’m gonna have to ask you to stop this. This is completely inappropriate. And not at all the forum to have this conversation.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Gerry, we've all known this was a possibility. And now it’s here. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So, seems to me this is the ONLY forum to have this conversation. Drew turns around from a row or two in front to talk to F respectfully.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Frank, I’m sure we all appreciate the point you’re trying to make, but there really isn’t any decision here. We need this. There are grumbles of support for Drew. Frank looks aroun and then slowly stands up. Next to him, his wife attempts keep him seated for a moment. People stop to listen.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. But, this thing here. It may not be the saving grace you all want it to be. Now, Gerry started this thing by saying that Natural Gas coming here is life changing... and it is. It’sa clean and efficient resource, but the way we go about getting it is some dirty business.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARDS
dialogues.text: With all due respect I think you’re out of your league. Steve and Sue look on. Richards tries to maintain control

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: And the potential for error is just too high and the results can be both horrible and irreversible.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARDS
dialogues.text: Thank you, Frank.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: There are reports from all over the country of people’s water being contaminated.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: No, no, no...

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: People who have to haul their own water from miles away. It’s harder to get enough for your crops and cattle-- Let alone to drink.  39

dialogues.speaker: RICHARDS
dialogues.text: Ok, Frank. I’ve absolutely had enough of this! We don’t have to-- All of a sudden Steve steps out from behind the bleachers Sue reaches to grab him.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Steve--

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (cutting her off without looking. ) I’ve got this.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Goddamn it. Steve arrives next to Richards completely calm.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Sorry I’m late, Mr. Richards. What did I miss? Everyone looks down to Steve... he has never been so publ in his career. Steve looks up at Frank.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Oh, I’m sorry I think I interrupted you Mrrrrrrrr?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Yates.... My name is Frank Yates.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Oh, Mr. Yates, are you connected with an environmental group? Frank chuckles.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Oh, what line of work you in, Sir?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I’m a teacher here at the high school.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: A teacher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I teach science. What about you, Mrrrrrrrr? 40 A few people chuckle at Frank’s confident retort, includi Steve.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: My name is Steve Butler. I’ma consultant, here, for Global Crosspower Solutions.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Ah, then you’re the man we have to thank for all that money.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I wish! No, I’m just the guy that works for the guy that works for the guy that may have had something to do with all that money. There are some laughs from the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I only heard the last part of what you were saying, but you sound like aman that’s certainly done his homework! Where, may I ask did you get all your information?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Mr. Butler, you and I both know the information I'm referring to is vast and detailed.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: You're probably right. And I’m sure I’m not the guy who has all the answers.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Oh, then you’d be the perfect guy for them to send to deny everything. Beat. Steve smiles and chuckles again.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Listen, I’m not going to deny that this issue has been made very complicated by a number of companies that have had their fair share of incidents. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 4l

dialogues.speaker: STEVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But, natural gas is not a new issue. We've been drilling in this country for over 50 years. And like any industry, you evolve. My company alone has invested millions and millions of dollars. Now why would we do that? If we’re this ‘evil machine’ that cares about nothing but the bottom line, why would we invest in something that is fatally flawed? Because instead of being one of the companies that is working to make the process “faster”, we chose to make it “right”!... For this exact moment. Because we knew if we figured out how to do it right... we'd be the only ones on the field. Frank smiles. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: But Global is being sued. Is that right, Steve? By numerous parties. Dealing with this exact technology.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Sure we are. Like any other company our size in every other industry. And we stand up to those people because we’re not in the business of handing out free money to people who make false claims. And we haven’t lost once.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Well, you can’t lose a game that’s still being played.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Look, Mr. Butler, I’m sure even you can admit that Fracking is far from a perfect process.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Perfect? (smiles) No, maybe not.. But with all the government restrictions they put on us and hoops we have to jump through, it’s pretty close to perfect. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: STEVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Heck, the only reason why natural gas is so big right now is because it’s finally the clean alternative TO the incredibly dangerous industries like coal and oil. If you know of another industry that’s cleaner than this and can have this big an impact on our country right now, please tell me, cause I'll go work there. Crowd smiles. Beat. If

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: If it’s such an incredible alternative why do they need a man standing off to the side of the room to make sure we all go for it? Seems like it should be able to sell itself. Steve stutters for even a moment we can’t see it.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: But you’re not the man with the answers.... So, who is? Because I still have questions...

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I can certainly try.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Well, good, I have questions about Fracking water; where they put all that water they shoot into the ground when it comes back up? That is highly toxic stuff. The air pollution from the well tanks, the potential for ground water contamination, the deadly effect on live stock and basically how would we live here when this is all over? Steve still somehow appears unflappable, hiding his all b lost composure.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: ... And I’m happy to answer all those questions. There’s no such thing as a neutral position here. If you're against natural gas, you’re FOR coal and oil. Unless we talk about cutting our consumption. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: STEVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And so far that’s a conversation none of us are willing to have. Frank smiles. There’s a long pause.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Steve, I just came here to point out that this issue is a bit more complicated than it seems.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Well, you've certainly done that.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Great, so I think we should take a vote?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Wait, what?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: In a few weeks, once everyone has had a chance to think this whole thing through, I think we should put it to a vote.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: But that’s not-- He turns to Richards, confident this isn’t possible.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARDS
dialogues.text: Oh for God’s sake. Frank, unfortunately this isn’t an issue that is in the realm of a town vote.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Gerry, the law states it is completely within the board’s power to relinquish any major decision to the will of the people... If they so choose. The crowd starts grumbling, seemingly with support for bo sides of the conversation.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Mr. Yates, with all do respect, I’ve talked to a lot of folks here who really need this. And I don’t think anyone here is going to be swayed by one man.  44

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You're right. Frank looks to the crowd. There’s a long beat. Suddenly, if on cue, a swell of people begin standing up. At first glance it would appear to be a majority of the crowd... w now know the reason for the big turnout. As they rise we see the rush of blood to Steve’s head. Of to the side, Sue’s eyes are wide.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: These people and I got together to say we strongly believe that this is NOT in the best interest of this town. A man runs up to Richards and whispers in his ear. This i the coach of the high school basketball team. We now see one of the doors of the gym, the team has entered and are standing off to the side ready for a practice.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERVISOR RICHARDS
dialogues.text: Uh... Yeah... yeah, sure thing, Stan. Go ahead. The boys immediately flood into the gym and go into lay u lines. Richards turns back and tries to compose himself.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERVISOR RICHARDS
dialogues.text: Well, this isn’t everybody, Frank. You know not even half the town is here today.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Exactly! And I think all those people would hate to be left out of such a big decision.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERVISOR RICHARDS
dialogues.text: Frank--

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Let’s face it, Gerry, money can often lead to bad decisions. You've seen the same numbers I have and with the recent figures on the deposits in this area at 150 million dollars, let’s all take some time to think it through. Richards looks over at Steve.  22 45

dialogues.speaker: SUPERVISOR RICHARDS
dialogues.text: 150 million dollars?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Those are the latest numbers out of the university. Steve says nothing... and that says everything. This registers like a freight train on Richards. He’s been dup and is immediately furious! Staring straight at Steve:

dialogues.speaker: SUPERVISOR RICHARDS
dialogues.text: Well 150 million dollars IS a lot of money.... Beat.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERVISOR RICHARDS
dialogues.text: Let’s have a vote! Steve goes to say something...

dialogues.speaker: SUPERVISOR RICHARDS
dialogues.text: Say, three weeks. We’re adjourned! Richards glares at Steve as he walks past him.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERVISOR RICHARDS
dialogues.text: Asshole... Time seems to have slowed down for Steve who has no idea to process what happened in the last 3 minutes. He looks over at Sue who is furious. The basketball team immediately rushes out around Steve, dribbling balls, as people begin to file out. From up above we see Steve just standing there at half co as he is completely surrounded... By this basketball team by this town.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. BRONCO
dialogues.text: Sue is behind the wheel driving furiously and fast.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Holy shit. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Holy SHIT!  46

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Calm down, Sue.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Don’t tell me to calm down! What was that? Stepping out on that court? What the hell were you thinking?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I was trying to fix things!

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Bull SHIT! You didn’t want to lose! You saw an old man beating up on your newest investment and you took that as some personal slight to YOU? He was just trying to score points on a town official, until you played right into him and handed him the whole game!! “Natural gas isn’t perfect?” What were you thinking? And what happened with the politician?... Why was he so pissed???

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: ++. I told him the number was 30 million.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ! Well, once again, you came in below the price point! Was it worth it??

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, Sue....

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Steve! I don’t give a shit about your numbers or your promotion! I don’t! My son is in fucking Houston with his stupid fucking dad. I don’t give a shit about being number one, I’m here to do a job and go home.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, Sue...

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Stop with the fuckin’ sorries!  23 47

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: «+. the plan is the same! But starting now we sign EVERYONE! I don’t care if they have 100 acres or 1 acre. We go door to door and we lease it all! We don’t lose. Steve nods, but is obviously rattled.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Nothing's changed. They still need the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sue and Steve are in Sue’s hotel room. They are Skyping w some people at the corporate offices. We recognize the ma in the forefront as David Churchill, the man Steve interviewed with.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: What are you telling us??? Are you telling us that we could actually LOSE this thing?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: That won’t happen. We just have to move quickly.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ! Do you have any idea what happens if this vote doesn’t go our way? It’s like a goddamn wildfire straight up the corridor! (Close to hysterical) If this gets out... the environmental groups get into this? Everything changes for us!

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I understand.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: DO you??? Do you have any idea how this will play at the shareholders meeting?? It’ll be a blood bath! A goddamn blood bath!! We’re sending the back up team now. We've just got to do an all out push on this town.  48

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Not a chance.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: With all due respect, if you send in more people from the company we immediately look like we’re running scared.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (Looking to try and see) .-. Who is that? A voice off screen answers “Sue Thomason”.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Steve and I can handle this.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Well we have to do SOMETHING!!! Jesus Christ! What happened, Steve??? You were supposed to get in, get out! Why the hell would you step out there and expose the whole goddamn thing? Beat. Steve looks at the screen.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: It was a judgement call. I don’t know, I guess I thought--

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Sir, it’s obvious they had planned this long in advance. The politician was buckling, that’s when Steve stepped in to try and put out the fire. This Yates guy is just a wild card.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: He’s the high school science teacher.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Well, we have him pulled up online... he’s a lot more than that! Frank Yates. MA, engineering, MIT. PhD from Cornell in Physics. Jesus Christ, the guy worked R and D for Boeing for 32 years? He retired, Steve! He's teaching for fun!

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I'll handle this, sir. This was my mistake. It’s a setback. Nothing more-—  24 25 26 27 49

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: I can have this entire town committed on paper before he can get one more supporter.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Give me the chance.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Well, we've got a lot to discuss here, Steve... I don’t think I need to tell you how important this is... this one’s all or nothing. We understand each other?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: ...I understand. The Skype clicks off, immediately lessening the amount of light coming from the screen. With no other lights on, St and Sue just sit silently in the glow of the computer. Su puts a hand on Steve’s shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: FADE TO BLACK
dialogues.text: INT. MOTEL - STEVE’S ROOM — MORNING 24 Steve opens the curtains letting in the morning sun. INT. MOTEL - STEVE’S BATHROOM - MORNING 25 From the room we see Steve in the bathroom brushing his teeth. Takes a small sip of water from a small plastic ho cup and spits it out. There’s one last sip and he drinks

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve walks down an oddly quiet main street. He is obviou in his own head. We follow him for a long beat until he comes to the Diner. Without looking up, he goes to open t door. As the door opens a wall of noise erupts from insid

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve enters and immediately looks up to see a bustling d buzzing with heated debate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve walks up to the counter of the retro diner to wait coffee through a mob of 10 others, shouting and arguing various opinions and feelings about the potential new industry. He is taking it all in as he stands stunned at register. Suddenly a voice.  28 50

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Coffee, handsome? Steve turns to see Lynn, the waitress from his meeting wi Richards.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Uh... two.

dialogues.speaker: LYNN
dialogues.text: Cream and sugar?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Yeah, thanks. Lynn hands him his coffees. Steve goes to pay. She touche his hand.

dialogues.speaker: LYNN
dialogues.text: No no, these are on me... Don’t you worry about Frank Yates, darlin’. We all know it’s not true. She winks. Steve doesn’t know what to say.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: LYNN
dialogues.text: Those folks can scream and shout all they want... they still need money. Steve exits. EXT. MAIN STREET — MORNING 28 As the diner door slowly closes behind Steve, the sound f into a complete silence once again. Steve walks along collecting his thoughts. A car is parked at the lone stop light. Steve looks up casually and then looks again. The man behind the wheel looks at Steve, smiling. There is a logo on the side of h car that reads ‘ATHENA’. As Steve gets across the street, turns back to look again, as the light changes and the ca drives on. Off Steve’s look:  51

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sue stands leaning against the hood of the Bronco checkin her phone. Steve walks up with the 2 coffees.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Hey, did research say anything about an environmental presence?

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: None of the usual suspects. Nothing locally.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Huh. He hands her a coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 52 We see Frank Yates wiping down a blackboard. Suddenly in doorway appears... the man that was in the car on main street. This is DUSTIN NOBLE. He is a tall man in his 30' and can immediately be identified as “outdoorsy.” He give warm smile.

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: Mr. Yates? Frank looks over.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Yes? Dustin walks in.

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: My name is Dustin Noble, I’m from an environmental group called ATHENA.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: What can I do for you?

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: Well... I heard about the vote. And I’m here to help out in any way I can. Frank smiles.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Look, I don’t think anyone in this town considers themselves to be members of some kind of movement or on the front lines of some great environmental revolution... I have a feeling we can win this. Dustin smiles.

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: With all due respect, sir, you've picked a much bigger fight than you think... so you have to win. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: And I have the one thing you don’t... Evidence. Dustin drops down 2 8x10 photos of a farm with dead cows front.  31

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve walks up a driveway, just as he did before, only th time the house is noticeably smaller than the ones we’ve before and the land much less expansive. Steve walks onto the rickety porch and stands in front of screen door. He pauses and takes a deep breath then rings the bell. A 6 year old boy appears at the screen door.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Hey there, are you the owner of this place?

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: (Smiling) Noooo!

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Then how come you’re doing all the work?  32

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED
dialogues.text: 53 32  33 54 INT. ROB’S GUNS, GROCERY, GUITARS AND GAS - DAY 33 Sue walks up to the counter carrying soap, toothbrush, toothpaste, deodorant and a bunch of cans of soup and Spaghetti O’s. Rob looks up.

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: There a storm coming I should know about?

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Looks like we’re gonna be here for a while.

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: Not necessarily a bad thing! Sue smiles at him as he starts to bag her items. Sue glan over and is shocked to see one of the windows has been shattered.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: What the hell happened?

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: Ah, I got into a bit of a heated discussion last night at the bar... I’m assuming that’s not a coincidence.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: A heated discussion? About what? Rob looks at her to say “I think you know.”  34 35 55

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: You gotta be kidding me.

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: It’s no big deal. Listen, they all need the money. Some of them just aren't ready to admit it, yet. Sue just looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. INT/EXT BRONCO - ROB’S GUNS, GROCERY, GUITARS AND GAS - D Steve is sitting in the truck, playing with the radio. He frustrated that there is no station. Suddenly you can bar make out a U2 song, then immediately returns to the aggressive sound of static.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Jesus! (to the radio) Come ON!! Suddenly Steve looks up and, in the rear view mirror, see Dustin filling his car with gas. Dustin looks over at him Steve gets out of the car just as Dustin finishes up.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Excuse me. Dustin gets in his car.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Excuse me! Dustin drives away. INT. ROB’S GUNS, GROCERY, GUITARS AND GAS - DAY 35

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: Hey, you sing?

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: You look like you'd be a singer.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: What does that mean?  56

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: Girls I knew in high school who sang in the choir had hair like yours. On his own body, he gently pats the area just above his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: I do sing, but I...

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: Told you. It’s in the hair. Think about it -- Diana Ross, Cher, Dolly Parton. They all had good hair.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: You're right... But, I don’t sing in public.

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: What? What’s the point of having good hair if you don’t sing in public? You should come with me tonight.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: To karaoke? Rob smiles.

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: We don’t call it that. It’s just open mic. You tell the band what you want to sing, they play it, you sing.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Not a chance. She gathers the bags of items on the counter.

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: Listen this whole door to door thing just isn’t gonna cut it. You wanna sell to these people? You gotta get ‘em all together or not get ‘em at all. Sue looks at him.  36 37 57

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: C'mon, I shouldn’t have to tell you this. Show your face tonight. Make yourself seem friendly. Embarrass yourself a bit.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: And if I do, you gonna sign your lease? She holds up a clipboard and points to his name on a list He smiles. EXT. ROB’S GUNS, GROCERY, GUITARS & GAS - DAY 36 Sue comes out of the store. She’s smiling.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Hey, did you see a guy in there?

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: I‘1l1 let you figure out how stupid that sounded.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I think there’s an environmental presence here.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Cuz there was just this guy and... I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: I gotta get a outfit. Steve looks over, taken aback! What does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sue has changed... not only physically, wearing an outfit that is neither to fit in, nor for business, but she seem also be in a different state of mind. Steve has changed h clothes too. They sit for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: So is this guy handsome?

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: (Immediately insecure) What?  38 58

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: No, you just look nice.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Shut up.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Scene of the crime.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Oh God, this is where you were?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: So am I sitting with you?

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: No, I’m gonna be with Rob.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Who's Rob?

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: The handsome guy. Beat. Steve can see she’s nervous.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: God, the things we do-- Sue goes to get out of the car.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Wait! Beat. Sue looks to Steve for encouragement.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: What song are you gonna sing?

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Oh, kiss my ass, Steve! She jumps out and slams the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sue spots Rob, who waves her over. He’s got a table near stage. Steve heads to the bar.

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: I signed you up!  59

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: For karaoke?? Rob smiles.

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: Yes. Drink? Rob gets the attention of the waitress. She starts coming over. Sue stares at the band... and the microphone standi there in front of them.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Maybe get me two. Rob laughs. 39 INT. BUDDY’S - NIGHT 39 Steve stands at the bar waiting for a drink.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Am I interrupting something? Steve turns to see... Alice.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Hey!...

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: (referencing herself) Alice. Steve laughs.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Now you go. We’1ll try this again.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Steve.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Pleasure to meet you, Steve. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: So it looks like you'll be here a lot longer than you thought. Steve looks up at her.  60

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: The town hall? Didn’t look like that went the way you wanted it to.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Yeah... I’m sorry I lied to you. We were only supposed to be here 2- 3 days.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: That’s ok. We don’t actually play a game called ABSOLUT MADNESS. Jesse’s shots were water. Right at that moment Jesse comes and sets the dusty bottl scotch in front of Steve. He smiles at Steve. Steve is totally confused.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: ...What’s ABSOLUT MADNESS? Alice smiles at him, knowingly. Then hands him a napkin w her number on it.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: In case of emergency only. She gets up to leave.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: See ya’ around, Steve. Oh, and congratulations, you got your picture on the wall. She leaves. Steve stares at her, smiling... still confuse Just as he’s about to call out to her... we hear a noise. It’s coming from the stage. Steve quickly turns to see... Sue singing ‘I SAW THE LIGHT’. She sings the lst line... silence... she sings the second. It is not good... but determined. Suddenly, the bar begins to slowly clap... on politely. Steve looks to Sue, mouth agape. Sue finishes to mild applause. She walks off stage to Rob

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: I thought that would’ve gone better.

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Don’t people go to church here?  61

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: Yeah... on Sundays. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: Hey look at it this way, now you have their sympathy. They’1ll never forget the woman who sang the Jesus song at open mic night. He smiles... she does not... then drains her third gin an tonic. She looks back at Steve who gives her a completely sarcastic thumbs up. Sue wants to kill him. Suddenly we hear a voice on the mic. Steve turns to see:

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
