dialogues.text: Hello? Hello? Testing. Could I have everyone’s attention for one second please? My name is-- There’s a squeak from the mic.

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: Whoa! Hot mic! Dustin laughs. The room is dead as they all look up at hi quizzically. Dustin is holding a stack of leaflets.

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: I uh-- I just arrived in town and wanted to introduce myself to all of you and uh-- Oh man, this seemed like a much better idea when I was standing in the back. Someone yells out!

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Sing something!

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: How bout this? If you give me just 30 seconds of your time, I'll even let you pick the song! There’s a few cheers and whistles.

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: My name is Dustin Noble and I work for a small environmental group called Athena. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We travel around the Northeast to protect environmental habitats and wildlife.

dialogues.speaker: CROWD
dialogues.text: Boooo! Steve and Sue look on a bit confused. Alice is now standi by the bathroom door.

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: I grew up in a small town in Nebraska, my family was a 5th generation farming family. Dairy. There’s murmurs of frustration in the bar. This is not wh they’re here for.

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: All our cows are now dead. The room is quieted slightly.

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: In March of 2008, my dad found 12 dead cows down by a creek a half a mile from our house. By April 80% of his herd was either sick or dead. And by Christmas he had defaulted on his payments and the bank eventually took his house. 9 months. 150 years that farm was in our family and it only took 9 months to lose it. It wasn’t just us. 16 other farms in that county went under. All the land just died. Shrivelled up and turned brown. Making it very easy to see the only things left standing. Giant green tanks that said GLOBAL. The room begins to turn as people take this in. Steve and Sue notice. Sue gets up and heads for the bathrooms. Stev takes his cue and follows her.

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: So, when I heard that you all were going to put this to a VOTE? Well, I had to come down here personally and tell you my story. This isn’t some environmentalist conspiracy. This is my life. The simple truth is... One day the farms were there.  63 Dustin holds up the leaflets.

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: And one day they weren't.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: What the hell is happening right now?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: That’s the guy!

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: My name is Dustin Noble. I’m just a hick from Nebraska and I’m here for you!

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: How much money do we have left? I got this. She turns and leaves. Steve stands looking on for one mor moment.

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: What’s that? There are a few chuckles.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Springsteen! Sing! There is a small amount of laughter. That leads to clappi Dustin looks around at the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: Oh man! I don’t know about that. That’s sort of sacred ground to-- The keyboard player begins to play lightly ‘DANCING IN TH DARK’. Dustin turns to her.

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: You gotta be kidding me! The rest of the band jumps in immediately! The crowd reac goading him more. He is screwed. Weakly he tries:  64

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: .-. I get up in the evening. And I ain’t got nothin’ to say. The crowd cheers. Dustin smiles.

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: I come home in the morning, I go to bed feeling the same way. I ain’t nothin’ but tired, man I’m just tired and bored with myself. Hey baby, I could use just a little help. Crowd joins in.

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: YOU CAN'T START A FIRE, YOU CAN’T

dialogues.speaker: START A FIRE WITHOUT A SPARK. THIS
dialogues.text: GUN’S FOR HIRE EVEN IF WE’RE JUST DANCING IN THE DARK. Now the bar is full-on cheering Dustin on. Steve looks ov and sees Alice watching Dustin. He walks right up to her. and takes her arm.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Hey, none of that stuff-- the things he said. It’s just not true. She looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I’m not a bad guy.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: I don’t think you are. After sharing a beat. He heads to the door, looking back Dustin. The ENTIRE bar is on their feet. People are danci and singing along. He has the entire bar in the palm of h hand.

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: They say you gotta stay hungry. Dustin, in full swing, grabs a girl.

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: HEY BABY, I’M JUST ABOUT STARVING

dialogues.speaker: TONIGHT
dialogues.text: 40 65 The place ERUPTS!!! At the door, Steve has had enough. He grabs a leaflet and walks out. We stay on Dustin and the for a few more moments. He is a huge hit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve and Sue stand outside in the parking lot. Steve is holding the leaflet which depicts a poorly xeroxed pictur what looks to be a dead animal with gas wells in the background. On the bottom in block print it reads... GLOB GO HOME.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: “Global go home”, what a crock of shit. Steve slaps his neck.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Can we go inside, Sue? I’m getting eaten alive! How do you even know he’s staying here?

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Where else is he gonna stay, Steven?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: None of that shit can be true, right?

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Of course not! We would’ve heard about it. They’re not going to send us in blind.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I should have just confronted him at the bar.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: In front of the whole town?... on open mic night??? Dustin’s car pulls up. Sue gives a know-it-all look to St

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Play nice. As Dustin gets out of the car, Steve walks up.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Hey man! What’s going on?  66

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: Not much. How you doin’?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: What’s that?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: What... are... you doing here? Athena? I’ve never even heard of that company. What kind of name is that?

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: It’s Greek, originally. Athena is the goddess of--

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Dude-- I fucking know who Athena is!

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: Ok, you just said you didn’t-- And, I’m sorry, who are you?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: You're kidding me, right? I’m Steve!... I’m the guy you were just talking shit about at open mic night!

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: Ah! You’re with Global.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Do you have ANY idea who you’re dealing with? Is this some kind of game to you? Somethin’ you and your stoner buddies can-- Sue puts a hand on Steve’s arm.

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: I know exactly who I’m dealing with. I know all about your company. I’ve seen what you do and I know how to beat it.  67

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Oh really? By telling bullshit sob stories and singing fucking Springsteen? You gotta be kidding me!

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Listen. You seem nice enough, but I hate to tell you you’re way out of your league, here. We’ve signed more than enough leases to move forward with our development.

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: I wouldn’t underestimate these people. They’re-- Sue steps toward him.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Trust me, they’re poor. They need the money. I know why you think you’re here and I admire your commitment. But your presence here is only going to confuse people. Beat. Dustin looks up at her. She looks at him firmly. As he looks back down, Sue reaches into her pocket and pulls an envelope.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: But, we do appreciate what you’re doing and would like to make a donation to your fine organization. After a beat. Dustin takes the envelope!

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: We appreciate your cooperation. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Great! Dustin picks up his bag and heads toward the motel. Steve shares a triumphant look with Sue.  41 68

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: He’s actually a nice kid.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Very nice.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Just confused.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Right. INT/EXT BRONCO - DRIVING - DAY Al Sue and Steve are driving through town not far from the hotel. We know this because though there is some land in between, the houses are closer together. Sue sees somethi in one of the few fields out the window. She points.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Okay. Check out the horses. Sue slows down. There are three horses off in the distanc Steve and Sue squint.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: They do seem small.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Next to the goats, see? It’s hard to tell for sure, but standing next to a few go the horses do look unusually small.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: They should be bigger next to the goats.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Right???

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: You're right!.... Unless the goats are big.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: C'mon! Those goats are normal! Sue starts to accelerate. Steve is beaming. Then suddenly

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Holy shit...  42 69 In the front lawn of the upcoming house there is a sign posted out front. It reads GLOBAL GO HOME. It is an enlarged and slightly clearer version of Dustin’s leaflet They drive by. Both Sue and Steve seem confused. Then, a few houses up, they see another one... and another one.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: What’s going on? Steve looks back to see the signs as they pass. As he tur back to face front:

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Son of a bitch! At that moment Steve sees, parked in the driveway of the upcoming house... Dustin’s car.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Pull over. Pull over!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Bronco pulls over to the side of the road, as Dustin walks out of the house with a large sign in his hand. It a large blown up version of the leaflets he’s been handin out which show a large photo of dead cattle and the words GLOBAL GO HOME on the bottom. A couple waves as he walks down the walkway. He is carrying a large cardboard poster with him. Steve launches out of the car, trying unsuccessfully to hide his fury. Dustin sees him.

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: (Full volume to spite Steve) Hey, Steve!

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (To Dustin under his breath) What are you doing? Steve gives an overly cheerful wave to the couple on the porch.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: HELLO! (To Dustin) What the fuck are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: I’m telling these people the truth. Dustin sticks the sign in the ground.  70

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: We had an agreement.

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: Did we? Dustin leans on sign. The couple looks on.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: We sure as (whispers) shit did.

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: Well, I guess I woke up this morning and realized I should do what I came here to do.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: You WHAT?

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: Yeah, I just feel morally obligated to stay. Indicating the sign.

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: Oh, I put that donation to good use! Thank you! Dustin waves to Sue.

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: Hey Sue!

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Are you fucking insane? Do you have any idea what you’re up against? We are a 9 billion dollar company. Do you have any idea what we're capable of?

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: Do you? Beat.

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: Because all I see here is you and me. And one of us is a lot more confident than the other.  71

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: You're absolutely right, and one of us is going to punch the other one in the face. The couple goes back in the house, a bit nervous. Dustin looks back and watches them go then turns back to Steve, concerned.

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: Steve, stop. Listen to me. You’re doing all the things you’ve done in the past... and they’re not working. Why is that?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Not working? We already have 60% of the land in this town bought and paid for. It’s over.

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: Steve, you can buy 80% of the land... that’s only 40% of the vote. Wake up, Steve, we’re not fighting for the land. We’re fighting for the people. Steve actually looks like he’s going to hit Dustin.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: You son of a bitch! Do you have any idea what you’re doing to these people? These people need help. We're trying to give it to them. What the fuck are you doing? From the truck:

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Walk away, Steve.

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: Your wrong, Steve. These people? They changed. It’s not just about the money any more.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Get in the car. He pats Steve on the shoulder.  43 72

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: Listen, none of this is your fault. This is just your time. You're going to lose. He begins to walk to his truck.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Really? To what? What are you selling?

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: See ya around, Steve. As Dustin gets in his truck.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Yeah, let’s just run everything on rainbows and laughter!... Dip shit. Steve walks to the truck, pissed.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT BRONCO
dialogues.text: Steve is stewing. After a moment. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Look, we’ve dealt with this before. We're fine.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: We just have to be smart, come up with a way to--

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (quietly) Turn around.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Ok, you've GOT to stop! What are you gonna do beat the shit out of this guy?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Turn around, Sue.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: This is completely infantile!

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Turn the car around, Sue!!!  44 45 73 Sue goes quiet and looks at him. After a moment... she begins to turn around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the car turn around and watch it drive off down th road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a large wide shot we see Steve and Sue from behind standing seemingly in the middle of nowhere. After a long beat.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Well, we've definitely got the space. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Food and games to the left, animals and bathrooms to the right. We might even have room for a tractor pull behind the ferris wheel back there with the whirly... thing. What am I missing?

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Come on, Sue.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: I’ve never even BEEN to a town fair, Steve. I’m not in P.R.! This is for the back up team.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: We ARE the back up team, Sue. And this is how we win. When I was growing up people would talk about the town fair for months. If we can’t sign everyone, let’s at least show them what its like to have some money. She looks at him as he stares off.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: What am I missing?  46 47 74

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: ....Bouncy castles... Steve smiles.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Congratulations, you just got a job in P.R.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve walks up to his room after a long day and puts the in the door. When he looks up, he sees that one of Dustin leaflets is taped to his door.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Asshole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We come up on an indecipherable background. A greyish wal After a beat: Dustin enters from out of frame as we pull out to reveal. black board.

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: Good morning, everyone! My name is Dustin! We immediately reveal... a classroom of kids.

dialogues.speaker: HI DUSTIN
dialogues.text: As we pull out more we see that in front of him is a brow bag of unknown supplies and on the floor is a large box. He’s talking to Alice’s 5th grade class. She stands off t the side, admiring.

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: How many of you live on a farm? Almost all the hands go up.

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: Alright! From behind the desk he pulls up a large clear bag full o dirt and places it on the table. He then reaches into the bag and pulls out a few toy figures of cows and horses.

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: Now, let’s say THIS is your farm!

dialogues.speaker: 5TH GRADER
dialogues.text: That’s a bag of dirt!  48 49 75

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: I know, I know! Geesh! Thought 5th graders were supposed to have imaginations. (He smiles) Ok, how about this! He picks up a pencil and waves it over the bag of dirt.

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: In Spectro Peculium! Poof! Now it’s a farm! Ok? The kids laugh!

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: Whew! Thank God for Harry Potter! We see that one of the children laughing is... Carson All Claire’s son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve is standing on a porch waiting. The door finally op and a large man stands inside the screen door.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Hey there! My name is Steve Butler and--

dialogues.speaker: LARGE MAN
dialogues.text: I know who you are. You outta be ashamed of yourself.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Look, the information you're getting from this ATHENA guy is not true. If you look at-- The large man slams the door.

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: And this... From behind the desk he pulls up a big clear Tupperware container and pours in a large bottle of water.  76

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: And THIS is all the water in town! The water you drink, the water the cows drink, the water your puppies and kittens drink and all the water in the river for the fish. Alice looks at him warily, a bit perplexed.

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: Now let me show you what happened one day in my home town, in a state called Nebraska, when this company GLOBAL, tried drilling for Natural gas. He holds the bag over the container of water. Suddenly he begins puncturing the bottom of the bag with a pencil.

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: See, they wanted to drill into the land, like this. The kids laugh at the rather destructive action. Little b of dirt start falling into the water.

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: But unfortunately they don’t just use a drill like the ones some of your daddies have. No, they use ones that shoot water and sand! Dustin takes a sports bottle and begins to shoot water in the bag of dirt. After a moment the bag begins dripping dirty water out of the bottom. The kids cheer!

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: But hold on, hold on! That’s not all! In order to do all that drilling they need to use... From the brown paper bag he pulls out 5 or 6 bottles of h cleaning products, etc.

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: Chemicals! Now these chemicals that they use seem harmless when they’re contained right? In fact a lot of the bad stuff up there you can find right here in the bottles under your sink at home. But they don’t use one chemical at a time. They use all of them.  50 51 77 Dustin starts to pour all the products into the bag. Alic pulls away a little from the smell. After a moment a gros concoction of dark ooze starts dripping from the bag.

dialogues.speaker: KIDS
dialogues.text: Ewwwww! They’re all a bit horrified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sue and Steve walk to the Bronco not paying attention. Wh they get in Steve looks up.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: God DAMN IT!!! The windshield is covered in the Athena leaflets with the photo of the dead cows and GLOBAL GO HOME written on them

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve exits a house saying goodbye to the older couple.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Well, I appreciate your time. If you change your mind, you let me know. They shake hands and smile. Steve walks down the walkway disappointed. Suddenly he hears a voice.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: There he is! Steve looks around and sees a man in his late 20’s sittin the porch of a neighboring trailer. He waves.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Hey! Steve keeps walking.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I’ve been waitin’ on you folks! Steve looks up at him.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Uh... Well, unfortunately I don’t think you’re, uh--  52 53 78 Steve looks into his folder.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Paul Geary. 442 Henley. On Steve’s list it is clear this man’s land is unusable. is listed at only 2 acres, which isn’t big enough to hous well. Steve clears his throat.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Oh, yup! There you are Mr. Geary, I apologize.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: No worries. Come on in, come on in! Where do I sign? Steve smiles. As he walks to the trailer his smile fades.

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: Now... He reaches into the box and pulls out a lighter. A few gasps.

dialogues.speaker: KIDS
dialogues.text: Whoa.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Oh, I don’t think--

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: It’s ok. Dustin lowers the lighter to the discolored water. After moment it IGNITES! Then burns gently.

dialogues.speaker: WHOA
dialogues.text: They all cheer. EXT. GEARY’S TRAILER - DAY 53 Steve is trying to leave. The door is open. We can see do the walkway... where Sue is standing. She gestures “What hell?”

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Well, thanks again for your time.  79

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You didn’t even finish your coffee!

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Oh man, if I had any more, I'd bounce out of here. But thank you! They shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Whoo! No, sir, thank YOU! You folks are doin’ a good thing here. We sure need the helpin’ hand. Steve feels a little sick.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Alright! Steve turns to the street where he can see Sue waiting in neighbor's driveway next door.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Hey, Steve! You got a good feelin’? Steve turns.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: About what?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: This well. You think it’ll be a gusher? Do they even call ita gusher?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Well, Paul there’s no way to tell til we do some tests--

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: But just your gut! Whatdaya think?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I think you seem like a lucky guy.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Whoo! Alright, well come back whenever with that contract!

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Alright. Paul goes back inside. After a moment’s pause:  80

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kids are cheering.

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: Why are you cheering?

dialogues.speaker: KIDS
dialogues.text: It’s so cool!

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: But that’s the water you drink.

dialogues.speaker: KIDS
dialogues.text: Oh yeah./ I guess. Needing a big finish, Dustin looks around the room and sees... on the windowsill is an aquarium. Inside is a ver unlucky turtle.

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: What’s the turtle’s name?

dialogues.speaker: KIDS
dialogues.text: Trigger!

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: Does his water look like it’s as clean as this water? A few kids answer quietly...

dialogues.speaker: KIDS
dialogues.text: No. No way. Silence. In a flash, Dustin has pulled the turtle out and back in front of the flames..

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: Well, let’s see if Trigger here can survive in his new home. BLOOD CURDLING SCREAMS FROM THE KIDS!!... and Alice. Dustin stops. He’s given the greatest presentation ever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kids are filing out. They all high five Dustin! Dusti gives them all sticker versions of the leaflet on the way out.  81

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: Stick these anywhere you can! Get in trouble!

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: (Laughing) Absolutely not! Wow, that was great! So vivid. Dustin smiles, joking.

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: I am good! Alice and Dustin laugh. A moment. The bell rings.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Well, thanks again.

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: No, thank you! They shake hands. He turns and runs down the hall. Alice watches him go. Suddenly we realize that a group of kindergartners have b coming down the hall, all led by their teacher... Gwen. A she walks by with the train of children she stares after Dustin too.

dialogues.speaker: GWEN
dialogues.text: Goddamn it! It’s your birthday everyday, isn’t it? 56 INT/EXT BRONCO - GEARY’S TRAILER - DAY 56

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Let’s just go.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: How much land does he have?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: 1.8 acres. Sue looks over. She knows what this means.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: How much?  57 82
Sue looks back at the house.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: And told him 15%.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: (Chuckles) That’s funny. Smart.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Let’s just go.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Listen, that’s five grand free for that guy! Sue goes to start the car, it doesn’t turn over again.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: (Smiling) Don’t say anything! Steve still looking out the window, isn’t even paying attention. They drive away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve knocks on a door. After a moment we reveal... Alice

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Well, hello. Alice smiles.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Hey! Steve smiles. Long moment where the two wait to see what this is. Steve smiles.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Are you the owner of this farm?... Are youuuu-- Alice Neary? Steve holds up a clipboard and points to her name. Reacti from Alice as her heart falls for a moment. Steve’s here pitch. She hides her disappointment valiantly.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Yes I am.  58 83 EXT. ALICE’S HOUSE - LATE DAY 58 We are wide as we see look out on an INCREDIBLLY beautifu vista in the perfect light of early evening. This is the land behind Alice’s house. Alice sits on a small bench ri at the top overlooking the view. Steve stands giving an energetic pitch to Alice. We can very softly hear the sou of running water.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: See you can tuck the wells in down behind that group of trees to the right. Steve looks at an aerial photograph on his clipboard of Alice’s land.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: And because of the way your property is laid out we could put an access road clear on the other side so you wouldn’t even hear the trucks. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (Jokingly) And we could actually put the cash machine right next to the couch I slept on. Alice smiles.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: This farm has been in my family for over one hundred years.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Exactly, and this money will keep it in your family for another hundred. You wouldn’t see any of this from the house!

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: (Smiling) .-. But I’d see it from here.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Look, you don’t have to decide now. Think about it. Beat. Steve turns to her.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (knowingly) I can always come back. He smiles. She smiles. They both know what this is.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Yeah, cuz you’re gonna be around for a bit! Steve laughs. They look out at the land. We hold on the t of them... a second too long. INT. MOTEL - STEVE’S ROOM —- MORNING 58A The clock reads 4:30 am. Steve is awake. After a beat he gets up and walks out of frame. INT. MOTEL - STEVE’S BATHROOM - MOMENTS LATER 58B Mirroring the first shot of the movie in the restaurant bathroom, Steve comes up into frame splashing water on hi face. He looks at himself in the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve walks into frame carrying a pile of lumber. He drop them down. Takes a second to look out over the land and t picks up a shovel and walks out a few feet and begins to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve is once again at the coffee counter of the retro di There is dirt on his clothes as he waits. Lynn comes up a hands him his coffee. Is her energy different? She doesn’ even look up at Steve.

dialogues.speaker: LYNN
dialogues.text: Two dollars.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Thanks, Lynn. She won’t even look at him. Steve follows her as she walk back to join a group that sits by the counter.  59 85 He looks down the bar and sees Dustin sitting with a bunc people telling a story. He sees Steve and waves. Off Steve’s face. EXT. DENNON’S FARM — DAY 59 Next to a small dilapidated house is a beautiful expanse land with a stream running through it. Steve stands by a fence with a man. This is Jeff Dennon, mid thirties. He i repairing a part of the fence that keeps the animals out the stream. Suddenly Steve grabs one of the fence poles a helps Jeff. Steve’s ability is completely second nature.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: We send more than one BILLION dollars overseas every DAY to fuel our need for oil. Now that’s just insane. To be spending so much money to buy oil? FIGHTING for so much oil? When we have one of the largest natural energy sources right here in our back yard! Now this guy from Athena’s going around lying to everybody and--

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Mr. Butler, you seem like a good enough man so I’m going to be straight with you so as to not waste your time... That little boy you saw when you came to the door? Steve nods.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: He lost his father, my brother, 6 years ago in Fallujah... So you don’t need to lecture me on the whole foreign oil dependency routine. But let me ask you one question, Steve. If I do this... what do I say to that boy? What am I telling him? What am I telling him about this farm that my daddy gave me and his daddy gave him? What am I telling him about what his daddy went to the desert to fight for? See, you and I both know that the only reason you’re here, is because we're poor. Steve doesn’t respond.  60 86

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: How many wells you got up near Manhattan? What about Philadelphia? Or Pittsburgh? Steve still says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: It’s alright. I get it. That's what we’re here for. Nothin’ new. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: But, you’ll never get what you came here to take from me... and to be honest, I don’t even like the fact that you’re here trying. Off Steve’s look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve works in the hot sun bringing bails of hay from the back of the Bronco and stacking them. He makes it look effortless. We finally see the farmer he once was. Where he’s stacking them we see several fully built animal pens There’s a mule in one of them. A large cart next to it. S arrives carrying a lemonade.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: I’ve only been handing out flyers for like two hours and I want to die. I don’t know how that Athena guy does it. (Noticing Steve’s progress!) Oh my God! How’d you do all this? Is that a donkey? Steve begins to walk through the area he has just set up. Sue follows.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: A mule, yeah, the guy down the street let me borrow him to help dig out the course.  61 87

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: What course?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Pig races.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: I don't like that you said that without even a smile. Beat. Steve has arrived at a little well. He expertly han pumps some water to splash water on his face. He then tak a long drink.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: You alright?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Yeah... I’m just sick of this shit. This thing will close them. Let’s end this and get the hell out of here. Sue pauses for a second, seeing his change.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Alright, then. Suddenly a pick up truck pulls up with two men in the fro and 4 men in the back. They get out and walk up. The driver... is Rob.

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: Thought you could use a little help. Steve is taken aback.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Uh, yeah-- Yes. Thank you. You could work on putting up those food tents.

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: You got it. Let’s go. The men walk past. Sue looks at Steve and smiles. INT. MOTEL - STEVE’S ROOM - MORNING 61 Steve finishes up getting ready and goes to head out the door. He looks back to see if he’s left anything as he op the door. When he turns back to leave...  62 63 64 88 He runs right into what seems like a wall. As he steps ba we realize what it is... Like a college dorm prank, Dusti has stapled a huge version of the poster across Steve's entire door. Steve has finally had it!

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: God DAMN it!!!! Without even looking at it, grabs the poster and, as if i street fight, wrestles with it, finally ripping it down t middle. Sadly exhausted, Steve throws the crumpled and be pieces of poster into his room. Furious, he leaves and sl the door!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sue sits on the front porch with Claire Allen. She is signing a lease. In the yard in front of them, Carson is throwing a baseball with a friend. They are both wearing their homemade baseball t-shirts. Sue watches them.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Is that it? Sue snaps out of it.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: That’s it! Claire puts her hand on Sue’s.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: ... thank you. Sue takes this in and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The work site is buzzing. There is now a large group of people working together to help Steve. Without any hesitation Steve unloads horses out of a truck, raises te with several other people, puts up fencing for the pens. the while he is... happy. We see now that he is completel in his element.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sue is sitting in the stands of a little league baseball game. Close on her, we can see that there is something different about her. She is completely at ease... almost like she’s somewhere else. Suddenly she begins clapping.  65 66 89 We pull out to reveal that there is a change of innings happening. Sue is sitting on the right field line. As one team heads towards Sue, the team from the opposite dugout taking the field. We track the boy heading towards first base. As he comes closer we realize... it is Carson Allen we can now see his shirt.... A brand new YANKEES jersey professionally done. He finally reaches first base and tu back to the field. On the back of his shirt we see the number ‘15’ and above that?.... GLOBAL written in bold letters. INT. GEARY’S TRAILER - DAY 65 Steve sits with Paul Geary. Paul finishes signing the fin page in a flourishing last signature. He laughs out loud looks across the table to Steve. Then suddenly he jumps u and heads to a cabinet under the sink and pulls out a bot that’s only a third full.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: For special occasions! He pours into 2 cheap, non matching, glasses and hands on Steve and clinks his glass. As Paul laughs in celebration Steve finally laughs too. It’s genuine. Paul’s energy is infectious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fair is now nearly complete, there are pigs in the pe food tents are up, even the ferris wheel is up. It looks great. Steve is now covered in dirt and sweat. He is directing several people where to put the port-a-potties, SUE walks up sipping on a lemonade. Steve looks at her drinking.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Again with the lemonade?

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: You don’t understand, it’s insane! Steve looks behind Sue. On the sidewalk is an 11 year old girl at a lemonade stand.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Jesus, she’s everywhere.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Well... Everywhere the people are, Steve. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: SUE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She’s a little raging capitalist... You should hire her now, while you can afford her. Sue smiles.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: It’s weird that you crack yourself up. Suddenly Steve sees something.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Holy Shit... Walking up to Steve... is Frank Yates.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: This is a great idea, Steve. Lotta people looking forward to this. Thank you. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: What are you doing here, Frank?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Thought you could use some help.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: This-- Look at the signs, Frank. This whole thing is sponsored by Global. Steve points to signs hanging over the various areas of t fair.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: It’s still a town fair, Steve... I’m not a communist. Now, where do you need me? Long beat.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Wanna help blow up the bouncy castles? Steve points him in a direction of the bouncy castles.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Sounds good.  67 68 91 He walks away as Sue and Steve just stand awestruck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Similar to the first introduction to the town, we follow pick up truck full of people as it drives down the road. There are 3 people jammed in the front and a whole bunch packed in the back. We pan through all the tired and dirt faces and then come upon... Steve. We hold on the whole group laughing about something and then hold as we watch truck turn down main street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The entire team working on the fair walks in and takes a in a group. Steve takes a head count and then walks to th bar. Jesse comes over.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Hey, Jesse. We’ll start with a couple pitchers, just leave the tab open. Jesse walks away as Steve wipes his face with a bar napki He is... happy. Suddenly:

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Nice work, Steve. Steve turns to reveal... Dustin.

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: The fair idea was... smart. Steve looks at Dustin.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Well, thanks Dustin, I’m sure that was hard for you to say. Beat. Dustin stares at Steve.

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: You like this job, Steve? Steve looks over.

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: You love what you do?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: On days like this I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesse, holding 2 pitchers of beer in two hands puts them the bar.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: And buy him a round on me. One of those fancy imported ones... anda granola bar if you have it! Dustin smiles and shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: .+-You think you have what it takes, Steve?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: To beat you? Absolutely. Dustin smiles.

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: Who know’s? You just might... (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I’1l drink to that! He raises his pitchers and cheers’ Dustin. Dustin smiles takes a swig. Suddenly, we hear the door open. Both Dusti and Steve turn to see... Alice. She stops in her tracks.

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: Hey!

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Hey...

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: You ready to go?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Steve just stands there trying to process.

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: Thanks again for the beer, Steve. Was really sweet. I’11 take it to go!  93 Dustin gets up and walks to Alice who still looks uncomfortably to Steve.

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: You guys have a great night! Dustin and Alice start to walk. Alice turns back to Steve

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Hey, I’m looking forward to the fair tomorrow... should be fun.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: ‘Night. They walk off. We hold on Steve who is still frozen, hold his pitchers like a jackass. 69 INT. MOTEL - SUE’S ROOM - NIGHT 69 Sue sits on the bed. She is Skyping with her son. She’s putting on a happy face, but something is hurting. There a commotion on the other end of the computer.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Well, I don’t know what to say. A no hitter?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: It was only 2 innings.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: I don’t care! Did anyone get on base?

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Then that’s actually a perfect game! That’s amazing!

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: It’s not the whole game, Mom. From the other side we hear other kids’ voices yelling “C ON Danny!”  94

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Well, you shouldn’t be on the computer with me! Suddenly another kid’s face pops into the frame.

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: Hey MS. T!

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Hi, Colin! The boy disappears.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Ok, go, go! Where you guys headed tonight?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I don’t know... Sarah Dayton’s having a party I think. Sue is trying her best to keep it together.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: «+. you look really nice.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Ok.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: I love you very much.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Ok, mom. Long beat. Then, with a wave, he’s gone. Sue just stares the remaining glow on the screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve exits the bar... a little drunk. There is a giant m finishing a cigarette outside. Steve takes a deep breath. The man holds out the pack of cigarettes.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: No thanks, I’m good.  71 95 He looks back up to the sky. Suddenly a car pulls up in front. It’s a brand new Corvette. The lights blind Steve, then go off. A door opens and we hear:

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Steve squints to see who it is as his eyes adjust. It’s P Geary.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: It’s Paul! Steve can’t believe what he’s seeing.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Is that your car, Paul?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Yes sir! Picked it up over in Barton 2 days ago! Isn't it beautiful? Figured I’d treat myself! Right??? He laughs. Steve is horrified... He tries to make conversation.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Is that... What is that color? Champagne?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Haha! No sir! That’s why I had to go all the way to Barton. That there is a very special color. They call it Gold Mist! Steve is speechless.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Whatchu drinkin’, scotch? I’m buyin’! As he heads inside. Steve stands staring at the car looki like he could be sick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's late. Paul is gone. Only a few people remain in the bar. Steve sits staring off into space it seems. After a moment we here a loud voice yell:  96

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Hey! Steve spins in his stool and through blurred vision sees source of the noise. 4 men, obviously farmers sit at a nearby table... One of them is Jeff Dennon, the man whose brother died in Fallujah. Steve looks away.

dialogues.speaker: HEY
dialogues.text: Steve doesn’t turn.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: I just heard you’re a-- someone told me you’re from Iowa?... Steve doesn’t react.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: And your daddy he was-- your daddy's a farmer!

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: ... Grandfather.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Doesn’t matter.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Now lemme aska... how do you sleep at night? Steve turns slowly, un-fazed.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: No, I wanna know. How’s it that you come through these towns. You seen these places, you seen these people. You look ‘em right in the eye... And you sell this shit. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: You know it. Oh, you know all about it. The gas... the water... the poison. You know it ALL. And you bring it right to us, you put it right in our faces and say drink. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: JEFF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And the worst part, the WORST part is you ain’t some slick suit wearin’ city shark. No sir... you know these people. You seen these people. You come from these people. And you still go for the kill.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: «+. it’s not true. Steve looks away.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Look at me. Steve doesn’t.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: I said look at me. Steve does.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: I want you to look me right in the eye--

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: --Right in the eye.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: --when you do it. Yeah, I want you to see me when you do it. DoTI look like your daddy? You gonna sell this shit to your daddy-- Steve looks away. And laughs. All the farmers now stand u and move toward Steve.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: You have somethin’ to say? Beat. Tensions are high. Steve turns to them finally.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: You people baffle me... How you just don’t get it.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Well, why don’t you explain it to us. What the hell are we missin’ here?  98

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Money. And I’m not talking about little pay increases. I’m talking about “Fuck you” money. Some of the men shift their weight but say nothing.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Don’t want to apply for college loans for your kids? This money says “Fuck you”, loans. You worried about car payments? “Fuck you”, payments. The bank’s gonna forclose on your family farm? “Fuck you”, bank. “Fuck you” money is the ultimate liberator. And underneath this town is “fuck you” money. You think long and hard about all those brutal days workin’. And the bullshit checks you get from whatever goddamn frozen peas company that’s buying. You think about how much you made on your best day... and then you think real hard about how much you made on your worst. Cuz let’s be real honest with each other, they’re all starting to look like that more and more aren’t they? These people? This town? This life? It’s dying and damn near dead. And you all see it coming! And you just won't get the hell out of the way. Why??? Pride? Of WHAT??? What have you got? And for fuck’s sake, how much of it is even yours??? Hell, I bet all four of you are collecting subsidy checks from the government. Well, when they stop comin’? When all that help stops comin’ and you've got nowhere to go? You'll remember this conversation and remember the guy who looked you right in the eye and said “Fuck you”. In a flash the biggest, quietest farmer walks forward and punches Steve in the face, immediately dropping him to th ground. We see it’s the LARGE MAN that shut the door on Steve earlier. The farmers stand over him and we can see they’re furious... but they also listened. It’s intense.

dialogues.speaker: LARGE MAN
dialogues.text: You’re an asshole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 99 The farmers walk out. Slowly Steve gets up and sits back his chair. He takes a deep breath. For the first time we see what Steve has been staring at before the Farmers cam over to him... Behind the bar, under all the bottles he notices a series Polaroid pictures lined up. Above the pictures is written big glittery letters “ABSOLUT MADNESS”. At the end of the row of pictures... is Steve. For the first time we get a glimpse into the horror that was Steve’s first night in t In the picture, Steve is ruddy faced and sweating... he almost doesn’t look human. He’s in mid-scream and holds u his hands in metal-fan fashion, fingers posed in the shap horns. He looks ridiculous... but in his head... he looks awesome. Underneath each picture is the name of a state o city. Under Steve’s it says ‘IOWA’ INT. MOTEL - STEVE’S ROOM - NIGHT 71A Steve sits on the bed staring off. We hold on him as he contemplates what just happened... and what is happening. Suddenly the phone rings. He looks over to it quickly. It rings again... he picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: «+. Alice?

dialogues.speaker: SUE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: No, but our rooms connect if you’re that desperate.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Jesus, Sue...

dialogues.speaker: SUE, (0.S)
dialogues.text: Just wanted to make sure you were behaving. Tomorrow's a big day.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Yeah, I got it.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Get some sleep, Steven.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Ok, I got it!

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Steve...

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Great job...

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: «..You too. Steve hangs up. As Steve stares, we hear the pre-lap of thunder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rain pours down on the town fair... Lights have fallen an dangle over the ground. The bouncy castles are half deflated. The banner at the front is heavy with water as ink runs off. Across the street, we see Sue and Steve’s Bronco.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve is sitting in the passenger seat. He and Sue stare silently out at the wreckage, illuminated by the headligh

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: ..-We lost.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Let's go. Steve stares a moment longer. Sue turns the key... the tr is dead. Sue leans back and sighs. Suddenly Steve reaches over and turns the key again... an one more time holding the key through a horrible sound. T truck is dead.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Stop. He doesn’t let go.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Steve! Stop! Steve begins turning the key over and over furiously. The he begins punching the steering wheel, until finally... h screams and jumps out of the truck.

dialogues.speaker: FUUUUUUUUUUCK
dialogues.text: 74 101 He begins kicking the truck over and over until he’s exhausted. He just stands in the middle of the street in dim glow of the headlights. Sue stares at him from inside She says nothing. Suddenly headlights come up on Steve standing in the rain getting soaked. He looks over. A car stops in front of hi and the window rolls down to reveal... Frank.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Nice day! INT. FRANK YATES’ HOUSE -- LATE DAY 74 Sue and Steve sit at the kitchen table with Frank and his wife Arlene. They’re finishing a warm and hearty meal -- turkey, potatoes, salad, homemade cranberry sauce, carrot cake. The red wine has been flowing, too... most of it go to Steve. He seems a bit dark.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: God! That was so good.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Really nice. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: ARLENE
dialogues.text: You’re more than welcome.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: I have to get the recipe for those potatoes, Arlene.

dialogues.speaker: ARLENE
dialogues.text: Of course! You cook, Sue?

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: I do. My son and I-- well, I make him help me. Sue pulls out her iPhone and shows her a picture.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: He used to stand on a chair next to me, but now he’s so tall. He likes cutting things, vegetables and all that. That’s how I get him to talk - - stand side by side, you know, working on something. Steve’s eating the last of the carrot cake.  102

dialogues.speaker: ARLENE
dialogues.text: So your husband watches him while you’re traveling for work?

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: My ex-husband watches him, yes, while I agonize.

dialogues.speaker: ARLENE
dialogues.text: (getting up, clearing dishes) Divorce is a monster. You just have to work double-hard, I imagine. Frank's father died when he was only 8. His mother always talked about the clarity of purpose. How helpful that was. There’s just you and the kid... nothing else. You know exactly what you have to do every day. Sue’s eyes reflect absolute recognition. Frank hasn’t tak his eyes off Steve... who is fairly drunk already. As Fra talks we begin to push in on Steve.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: What about you Steve? Where did you say you were from? Iowa?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Eldridge.

dialogues.speaker: ARLENE
dialogues.text: (laughs ) Oh yeah? Any family still up there?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: «e+. No.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Wait a minute did you say Eldridge? Didn't they have a-- a plant up there?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Caterpillar plant. Steve nods. He’s in his own world.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Yeah, that’s right. Had a friend from Boeing who was from there. I remember that. Wasn’t pretty.  103

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: When they closed it, that was it.... The town was hollowed out. Sue looks at Steve. If she’s heard this information befor it’s never revealed Steve in quite the same way.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: What, and no pretty lady to hand out free money and save you? Sue smiles... a half smile. Steve doesn’t respond.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Yeah, Steve, and what if there had been?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (Quiet) I'd move so fuckin’ fast. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I’d take that money and leave... (Pointed) Just leave. The room is silenced. After a beat.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (Gently) ... And where would we all go? This lands on Steve. He says nothing. The room says nothing. Suddenly Steve excuses himself and walks out ont the back deck. The other three just remain seated. 75 EXT. FRANK YATES’ PORCH (MOMENTS LATER) - LATE DAY 75 Steve stands looking over the rail of the porch onto the expansive land behind Frank’s house. In the dwindling lig it is not only beautiful... it’s close to perfect. After long moment Frank exits the house carrying 2 cups of coff Steve is staring intently at something. As Frank joins Steve, we finally get to see what he’s looking at... It’s horse, perfectly proportioned but very small, standing ou Frank’s barn.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Miniature horse.  104

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Oh my God, we thought we were losing our minds. We kept seeing them from a distance, and couldn’t tell -- it was altering our whole sense of perspective. The horse grazes on a bale of hay. A dog sits nearby.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: A lot us breed them. They eat like rhinos. Some people think they’re some kind of abomination. Big industry up here.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: What do they get for ‘em?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Not enough, Steve. Steve finally smiles. Frank smiles with him.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You’re a good man, Steve. Steve looks over. Frank continues looking out.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You have so many of the qualities we need more of these days. Steve doesn’t know what to say.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I just wish you weren’t doing this. This hits Steve like a brick. He looks at Frank, perhaps say something... but is completely disarmed.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You know, I used to work up at some stables just north of here. They used to have a poker game every Friday night, the farm hands and the stable boys. One of the favorite stories in town was the night I took 50 dollars from the owner, Russ Clayborn. I had raised him 20 dollars. And scared him into folding a full house. That was 2 weeks pay! (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat. Beat. Beat. Beat. Beat. Beat. 105-106

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I was 18 years old and I ran all the way home holding three months of our mortgage. I was so damn proud. (Frank chuckles. Steve smiles.) I ran into the house, threw the money on the kitchen table and told my mom I bet everything on a pair of 3’s and won.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: She took one look at the money... and kicked me out of the house. Had to stay at my aunt’s for a week... When I asked her why she just said “You could have lost”. Steve looks over at Frank, but says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: In those days it was harder to find aman that was willing to bet it all.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: We have nothing left to sell and we can't afford to buy anything. You came here to help us. Offer us money... All we had to do to get it was be willing to scorch the earth under our feet. Neither man says anything.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Don’t get me wrong, Steve, I’m not better than my neighbors -- hell, I need the money too.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (Chuckles) I guess I’m just lucky... lucky to be old enough to have a shot at dying with my dignity. Frank heads inside. Turns at the door.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Let me know when you’re ready to head back. We hold on Steve’s face. Frank walks to the door. He suddenly stops... and without turning back:

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I’m so worried for us, Steve...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve and Sue walk in the front door. Steve is still ina haze.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Get some sleep, Steve. She walks off. Steve turns to a make shift coffee maker a pours himself a cup. Suddenly the woman behind reception says.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Excuse me. Excuse me, sir? Steve doesn’t respond.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Steve? Steve turns... but says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: There’s a package here for you. Steve walks up and gets it. It is a poster canister packa with GLOBAL return address sticker in the corner. Instead an address it just says his name.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Thank you. INT. MOTEL —- STEVE’S ROOM - NIGHT 75AA We are close on Steve as he opens the package on his bed. pulls out the contents and we immediately see a note writ in bold that says URGENT!!!: FROM RESEARCH DEPARTMENT. SUBJECT: DUSTIN NOBLE. Underneath the note is paperwork o an insurance claim and other statistics. All of which Ste breezes through until he gets to... a large photo. We immediately recognize something familiar... the dead cows As Steve looks harder we see the building behind the cows recognize it as the same building in the background of Dustin’s leaflets. But this photo is from a different ang and much wider, now showing the surrounding farm and land rather than just the cows and the barn behind it. Red circles are around objects in the background. After takin it all in and processing as fast as he can...

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Holy shit!  76 77

dialogues.speaker: 107-109A
dialogues.text: Steve jumps off the bed and runs out of frame with the poster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve thunders down the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve is frantically banging on a door. He waits a beat, then pounds again. After a moment the door opens to reveal... Sue. Steve bursts into the room.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: We got him. We GOT him!

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Don’t ever do that again.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: His whole sob story is bullshit!! I knew it! It was the only way he could beat us! Steve throws some paperwork on the bed and begins to open poster.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: What are you talking about? What is that?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Research ran a check! They found this! He lied! It’s some bullshit claim that has nothing to do with us!

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Why, what does it say?? Sue reaches for the paperwork on the bed, but just then S fully unveils the poster.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Sue!... What is this?

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: It’s the photo of his farm.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: And where is this farm?

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Where is this farm?

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Nebraska.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: And what's this? Steve points to something in the background of the photo. Sue looks at it.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: A silo.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: .-. Look closer. Sue squints... then:

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: «+. Holy shit. Steve smiles HUGE!

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: THAT is a fuckin’ lighthouse!

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Holy Shit.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Now geography was never my strong suit, but I’m pretty sure there are no oceans in Nebraska.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: «+. He made the whole thing up.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: And when this town finds out? That he lied? That he manipulated these people to get their vote? They’re gonna have fucking FIELD day with this guy. Sue looks at Steve.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: We win.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: «+. We win.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sue and Steve bang on a door. No response.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Dustin! They both bang again.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Gotta talk to ya’ man! No response. INT. RICHARD’S OFFICE Richards sits in his low lit office. The phone rings. Aft a moment he picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARDS
dialogues.text: Hello?... Hey, Steve... What??... Jesus!!... EXT. ALICE’S HOUSE - NIGHT Steve knocks on a door. He is holding the poster. After a moment, Alice opens. She can see something is wrong. There’s a long pause as they stare at each other.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Dustin’s a liar... Steve hands her the poster. She begins to look at it.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He lied about everything.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: What are you talking about? He points to the lighthouse. He knows she’ll get it.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I just came from Richards’. The whole town will know by morning. But I wanted you to hear it from me.  78

dialogues.speaker: 107-109D
dialogues.text: She looks up at Steve.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You deserve someone who tells the truth.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Why did you come here, Steve?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I told you... I’m not a bad guy. Good night, Alice. He turns and begins to walk. Suddenly her turns.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey, if I HAD asked you out--

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: -- I would've said yes. Pause. Steve finally smiles.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Good night, Steve. Smiling, she shuts the door. Off Steve’s look:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve walks up the street to the parking lot. He is deep thought. Suddenly, we hear a door close. Steve looks up t see... Dustin. They stare at each other, frozen for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: What you did is going to hurt a lot of people. Dustin walks to the car without speaking.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What were you thinking, man? I mean, how does somebody do that? You base your entire case against us on a lie?

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: Look, I just talked to Richards. Just let me leave.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Did you not think we were gonna find out? I mean, Jesus. You just guaranteed us the win.

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: You’re gonna lose, Steve.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: It might not be Athena who does it, but one of these days, you’ll lose. I just hope I’m there to see it!

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Well, I can guarantee it’s not gonna be Athena. Do you have any idea how bad this is? Athena’s done. It’s over for you.

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: What else was I supposed to do, Steve? This isn’t a fair fight. Jesus Christ, I go around doing what? Handing out leaflets and posters? I’m out there on my own! I’ve got nothing man! This vote meant everything! I had too!

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: No. You didn’t have to. You fucked up.

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: Then what else am I supposed to do? You tell me, Steve. In a world where nobody cares. Where a company like yours can do that in Lafayette, Louisiana. Or here in Mckinley. Or the next place you go. Because you know it’s gonna happen again and again. So you tell me, Steve, What am I supposed to do? Long Pause.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I never said this farm was in Lafayette, Louisiana...  Pause.

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: What?... What are you talking about???

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I never told you this happened in Lafayette, Louisiana. How could you know that?

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: Those people needed my help, Steve. They called ME!

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: No, they didn’t. You said yourself we're too clever. We make sure in all that fine print that they’re never allowed to call anyone. Definitely not an environmentalist.

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: Ok, Steve...

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Dustin, how did you know where this farm was? Pause. Dustin looks off. Long beat. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ, where did you even get these pictures for your posters.

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: Steve.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ, Dustin-- why are you here?

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: Fuck!... That was stupid. I should've just gotten in the car.

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: We were never gonna let them vote.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve is completely taken aback. After a long moment... I hits him.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: ++. You're with Global. Jesus Christ, you're with global.

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: Did you really think a they were going to leave something like this in your hands? After you let them bring it to a vote? Come on, companies like Global don’t rely on anyone. That’s how they win. They win by controlling every outcome. They do that by playing both sides...

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: But I’ve been--

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: What?... What did you do, Steve? What is it you think you did? I did everything. All this is me. Athena is me. This story is me. Getting you the package to take to the politician... is me. See, you've only done what I’ve allowed (expected) (Supposed to) (wanted) (Knew you) (predicted) you to do... And you did your job. It worked. It’s done. We win. Beat. Steve says nothing. Steve looks up.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: So, this farm--

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: Oh come on Steve, stay with me. This farm doesn’t matter. They've already dealt with this. That’s done.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: They said it was a false claim.

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: Steve.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: But, this happened... this happened.

dialogues.speaker: DUSTIN
dialogues.text: Of course it happened... And now, let me give you a bit of advice... you’re gonna want to stop asking questions. You’re at the big kids table. Beat. Dustin looks into Steve’s eyes. DUSTIN (CONT’D) You’re a good choice for this, Steve. You’ll do a good job. Good luck in New York. Dustin walks to the truck and opens the door. He starts t car and in a moment he’s gone. Steve just stands alone in the parking lot, devastated... still holding the poster. After a moment he turns to the door of the motel. Standin behind the screen door... is Sue.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Funny. Smart.  79

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED
dialogues.text: 110 79  111 TOA INT. ROB’S STORE - AFTERNOON TOA Sue is walks up to the counter with a pack of gum. Rob lo up and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: That’s it?

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: That’s it.

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: Sorry, I can’t make the vote.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: (Knowingly) I think we'll be ok. As Rob rings her up:

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: (Smiling) I’ve got you figured out.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Oh yeah?

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: You don’t really care about any of this. You only want to get home to your kid... And I think that’s terrific. This reaches Sue more than she’ll ever show. Rob looks at her and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: Well, that’s that.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: That’s that. They both know this was their goodbye. Sue turns and leav

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see a mirror. One again, Steve pops up into the frame splashing water on his face. We widen out to reveal... he in a high school bathroom. He looks at himself in the mirror. We can hear the rumblings of a large group of peo in the background. We hold on Steve. The sounds get loude as we cut to: INT. HIGH SCHOOL GYMNASIUM —- AFTERNOON 80 In the stands, once again, a crowd is gathered... much la than the first time. Once again many of them are holding lemonades. Steve enters through the door holding the tape together poster. He looks out to center court where Richa is getting ready to begin.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARDS
dialogues.text: Ok, so if everyone can take their seats please? We have a lot to get to today.  113 Steve seems tense... nervous. Suddenly:

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Lemonade? Steve turns to see, just a few feet away from him is... t lemonade girl.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Is it good?

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Really good. Steve looks and sees she has set up right in between the and the stands.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: You got a good spot here.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: I know. The girl smiles. Steve smiles back and picks up a cup. He takes a sip... tasting it for the first time.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: --. Wow.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: I know. She smiles. He places a dollar on the table and picks up poster, readying himself. We suddenly hear the sound of coins.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Mister? Steve turns.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: You forgot your change.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Oh, no, no. That’s for you! The girl is confused... and then puts her arm out holding change.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: The sign says it’s only twenty five cents. So... it’s only twenty five cents.  81 114-115 This honesty and purity hits Steve... he reaches his hand and takes the change. Looking down at her looking at him.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: ... Really good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man comes up and stands next to Richards. He indicates basketball team at the other door, now in uniform.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARDS
dialogues.text: (To the coach) I know, I know. We’re just gonna be a few more minutes. (Back to the crowd) Now before we get to the vote, Steve Butler just wanted to say a few words. Steve arrives at center court and looks out to the bleach Sue sits in the front row. Steve looks around and takes s of the familiar faces he has come to know; Drew, Jeff, Claire, Arlene, Frank, etc. He lands on Alice. She looks back at him. He gives her a small smile.  116-117 Steve holds up the poster. He looks out at the crowd. After a long pause:

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I know there’s been a lot of talk about this poster. So I figured I'd just show you all. He shows them. Pause. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I was looking at this picture for a while last night. A long while... But, I found myself staring at this barn. The wood on the side is buckling. Probably from all the salt water in the air. The paint’s chipping and the flag is fading. It reminded me of my grandfather's barn... That barn was the bane of my existence... it was immaculate. It seemed like every other summer we were out painting that thing. Hours and hours... in all that heat. And I remember asking him why. Why do we have to do this? And he'd just look at me and say “It’s our barn. Who else is going to do it?”

dialogues.speaker: STEVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I always thought he was crazy... And stubborn... and Proud. Steve looks to Alice.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But I think he was just trying to teach me how to take care of something.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You all know Dustin lied... That he made up a story to get you to vote the way he wanted you to and in the end... that’s exactly what he did. Dustin isn’t an environmentalist. Dustin works for Global. Global couldn't afford an environmental presence... so they created their own. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: STEVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They wanted to make the decision for you... and they were betting that you’d let them. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They were doing all this to protect themselves. Because this isn’t Dustin’s farm... but it did happen. This is a Global farm. Now, I’m not saying this would happen here. But they know the only reason we're all in this room... is to ask... what if it did. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I don’t know what the answer is anymore... But at this point? Where we are? We’re betting a lot more than we think. Everything we have-- everything we are is on the table now... And it’s just not ours to lose.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is still our barn. No matter what they do... no matter what they think... it’s still our barn... that’1l never change. Steve just stands. No one says anything. Sue just stares him. After a moment, he sees the players in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: «+. Go Pioneers. Steve heads for the door, a man with purpose. EXT. GYMNASIUM —- PARKING LOT 82  118 Sue leans on the front end of the Bronco. Suddenly she lo over to see... Steve walking out of the gymnasium. She’s finishing up a phone call.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: «+. I understand. She doesn’t even look at Steve as he walks up to the Bron She hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Was that them?

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Yes... You're definitely fired.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: And you?

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: «+. They want to see me in the city tomorrow... Steve smiles. Sue walks around the car and gets in. Steve comes around to the passenger side door.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Congratulations. Beat. Sue is processing all of this at once.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Can I give you a lift somewhere?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: C'mon, Sue. Beat. She looks up at him.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: It’s open mic night! Sue smiles. Then her smile fades. She pauses and looks forward...

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: It's just a job... She starts the car. Looks back at him.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: --- Oh, for the love of God, at least get some new boots.  119 Steve smiles.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: «+. Not a chance. She drives off. Steve just stands and watches the car drive away... Then a turn and disappear. He is now alone. Quietly we begin to hear music... Steve finally turns and walks across the street. As we follow him we finally see... Buddy's. The music begins to build. Steve looks to the bar and barely, but enough, we can see sign... OPEN MIC NIGHT. The camera widens... as Steve enters the bar. And as the camera continues to rise we see ... for the first time... shot of this main street... the first full picture of thi town.
